    1530. 

  1530.  
    1531. 

  1531. 1var ComplexExpression = define([Expression, AliasMethods, CastMethods, OrderedMethods, SubscriptMethods], {
    1532. 

  1532.      instance:{
    1533. 

  1533.          /**@lends patio.sql.ComplexExpression.prototype*/
    1534. 

  1534.  
    1535. 

  1535.          /**
    1536. 

  1536.           * Represents a complex SQL expression, with a given operator and one
    1537. 

  1537.           * or more attributes (which may also be ComplexExpressions, forming
    1538. 

  1538.           * a tree).
    1539. 

  1539.           *
    1540. 

  1540.           * This is an abstract class that is not that useful by itself.  The
    1541. 

  1541.           * subclasses @link patio.sql.BooleanExpression},
    1542. 

  1542.           * {@link patio.sql.NumericExpression} and {@link patio.sql.StringExpression} should
    1543. 

  1543.           * be used instead of this class directly.
    1544. 

  1544.           *
    1545. 

  1545.           * @constructs
    1546. 

  1546.           * @augments patio.sql.Expression
    1547. 

  1547.           * @augments patio.sql.AliasMethods
    1548. 

  1548.           * @augments patio.sql.CastMethods
    1549. 

  1549.           * @augments patio.sql.OrderedMethods
    1550. 

  1550.           * @augments patio.sql.SubscriptMethods
    1551. 

  1551.           *
    1552. 

  1552.           * @throws {patio.sql.ExpressionError} if the operator doesn't allow boolean input and a boolean argument is given.
    1553. 

  1553.           * @throws {patio.sql.ExpressionError} if the wrong number of arguments for a given operator is used.
    1554. 

  1554.           *
    1555. 

  1555.           * @param {...} op The operator and arguments for this object to the ones given.
    1556. 

  1556.           * <p>
    1557. 

  1557.           *     Convert all args that are hashes or arrays of two element arrays to {@link patio.sql.BooleanExpression}s,
    1558. 

  1558.           *          other than the second arg for an IN/NOT IN operator.</li>
    1559. 

  1559.           * </p>
    1560. 

  1560.           */
    1561. 

  1561.          constructor:function (op) {
    1562. 

  1562. 7746            if (op) {
    1563. 

  1563. 6989                var args = argsToArray(arguments,1 );
    1564. 

  1564.                  //make a copy of the args
    1565. 

  1565. 6989                var origArgs = args.slice(0);
    1566. 

  1566. 6989                args.forEach(function (a, i) {
    1567. 

  1567. 14194                    if (Expression.isConditionSpecifier(a)) {
    1568. 

  1568. 6                        args[i] = BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs(a);
    1569. 

  1569.                      }
    1570. 

  1570.                  });
    1571. 

  1571. 6989                op = op.toUpperCase();
    1572. 

  1572.  
    1573. 

  1573. 6989                if (N_ARITY_OPERATORS.hasOwnProperty(op)) {
    1574. 

  1574. 1134                    if (args.length < 1) {
    1575. 

  1575. 0                        throw new ExpressionError("The " + op + " operator requires at least 1 argument")
    1576. 

  1576.                      }
    1577. 

  1577. 1134                    var oldArgs = args.slice(0);
    1578. 

  1578. 1134                    args = [];
    1579. 

  1579. 1134                    oldArgs.forEach(function (a) {
    1580. 

  1580. 2547                        a instanceof ComplexExpression && a.op == op ? args = args.concat(a.args) : args.push(a);
    1581. 

  1581.                      });
    1582. 

  1582.  
    1583. 

  1583. 5855                } else if (TWO_ARITY_OPERATORS.hasOwnProperty(op)) {
    1584. 

  1584. 5792                    if (args.length != 2) {
    1585. 

  1585. 0                        throw new ExpressionError("The " + op + " operator requires precisely 2 arguments");
    1586. 

  1586.                      }
    1587. 

  1587.                      //With IN/NOT IN, even if the second argument is an array of two element arrays,
    1588. 

  1588.                      //don't convert it into a boolean expression, since it's definitely being used
    1589. 

  1589.                      //as a value list.
    1590. 

  1590. 5792                    if (IN_OPERATORS[op]) {
    1591. 

  1591. 23                        args[1] = origArgs[1]
    1592. 

  1592.                      }
    1593. 

  1593. 63                } else if (ONE_ARITY_OPERATORS.hasOwnProperty(op)) {
    1594. 

  1594. 63                    if (args.length != 1) {
    1595. 

  1595. 0                        throw new ExpressionError("The " + op + " operator requires only one argument");
    1596. 

  1596.                      }
    1597. 

  1597.                  } else {
    1598. 

  1598. 0                    throw new ExpressionError("Invalid operator " + op);
    1599. 

  1599.                  }
    1600. 

  1600. 6989                this.op = op;
    1601. 

  1601. 6989                this.args = args;
    1602. 

  1602.              }
    1603. 

  1603.          },
    1604. 

  1604.  
    1605. 

  1605.          /**
    1606. 

  1606.           * Converts the ComplexExpression to a string.
    1607. 

  1607.           *
    1608. 

  1608.           * @param {patio.Dataset} [ds] dataset used to created the SQL fragment, if
    1609. 

  1609.           * the dataset is ommited then the default {@link patio.Dataset} implementation is used.
    1610. 

  1610.           *
    1611. 

  1611.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.ComplexExpression}.
    1612. 

  1612.           */
    1613. 

  1613.          toString:function (ds) {
    1614. 

  1614. 6586            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    1615. 

  1615. 6586            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    1616. 

  1616. 6586            return ds.complexExpressionSql(this.op, this.args);
    1617. 

  1617.          }
    1618. 

  1618.      },
    1619. 

  1619.  
    1620. 

  1620.      static:{
    1621. 

  1621.          /**@lends patio.sql.ComplexExpression*/
    1622. 

  1622.  
    1623. 

  1623.          /**
    1624. 

  1624.           * Hash of operator inversions
    1625. 

  1625.           * @type Object
    1626. 

  1626.           * @default {
    1627. 

  1627.           *      AND:"OR",
    1628. 

  1628.           *      OR:"AND",
    1629. 

  1629.           *      GT:"lte",
    1630. 

  1630.           *      GTE:"lt",
    1631. 

  1631.           *      LT:"gte",
    1632. 

  1632.           *      LTE:"gt",
    1633. 

  1633.           *      EQ:"neq",
    1634. 

  1634.           *      NEQ:"eq",
    1635. 

  1635.           *      LIKE:'NOT LIKE',
    1636. 

  1636.           *      "NOT LIKE":"LIKE",
    1637. 

  1637.           *      '!~*':'~*',
    1638. 

  1638.           *      '~*':'!~*',
    1639. 

  1639.           *      "~":'!~',
    1640. 

  1640.           *      "IN":'NOTIN',
    1641. 

  1641.           *      "NOTIN":"IN",
    1642. 

  1642.           *      "IS":'IS NOT',
    1643. 

  1643.           *      "ISNOT":"IS",
    1644. 

  1644.           *      NOT:"NOOP",
    1645. 

  1645.           *      NOOP:"NOT",
    1646. 

  1646.           *      ILIKE:'NOT ILIKE',
    1647. 

  1647.           *      NOTILIKE:"ILIKE"
    1648. 

  1648.           * }
    1649. 

  1649.           */
    1650. 

  1650.          OPERATOR_INVERSIONS:OPERTATOR_INVERSIONS,
    1651. 

  1651.  
    1652. 

  1652.          /**
    1653. 

  1653.           * Default mathematical operators.
    1654. 

  1654.           *
    1655. 

  1655.           * @type Object
    1656. 

  1656.           * @default {PLUS:"+", MINUS:"-", DIVIDE:"/", MULTIPLY:"*"}
    1657. 

  1657.           */
    1658. 

  1658.          MATHEMATICAL_OPERATORS:MATHEMATICAL_OPERATORS,
    1659. 

  1659.  
    1660. 

  1660.          /**
    1661. 

  1661.           * Default bitwise operators.
    1662. 

  1662.           *
    1663. 

  1663.           * @type Object
    1664. 

  1664.           * @default {bitWiseAnd:"&", bitWiseOr:"|", exclusiveOr:"^", leftShift:"<<", rightShift:">>"}
    1665. 

  1665.           */
    1666. 

  1666.          BITWISE_OPERATORS:BITWISE_OPERATORS,
    1667. 

  1667.          /**
    1668. 

  1668.           * Default inequality operators.
    1669. 

  1669.           *
    1670. 

  1670.           * @type Object
    1671. 

  1671.           * @default {GT:">",GTE:">=",LT:"<",LTE:"<="}
    1672. 

  1672.           */
    1673. 

  1673.          INEQUALITY_OPERATORS:INEQUALITY_OPERATORS,
    1674. 

  1674.  
    1675. 

  1675.          /**
    1676. 

  1676.           * Default boolean operators.
    1677. 

  1677.           *
    1678. 

  1678.           * @type Object
    1679. 

  1679.           * @default {AND:"AND",OR:"OR"}
    1680. 

  1680.           */
    1681. 

  1681.          BOOLEAN_OPERATORS:BOOLEAN_OPERATORS,
    1682. 

  1682.  
    1683. 

  1683.          /**
    1684. 

  1684.           * Default IN operators.
    1685. 

  1685.           *
    1686. 

  1686.           * @type Object
    1687. 

  1687.           * @default {IN:"IN",NOTIN:'NOT IN'}
    1688. 

  1688.           */
    1689. 

  1689.          IN_OPERATORS:IN_OPERATORS,
    1690. 

  1690.          /**
    1691. 

  1691.           * Default IS operators.
    1692. 

  1692.           *
    1693. 

  1693.           * @type Object
    1694. 

  1694.           * @default {IS:"IS", ISNOT:'IS NOT'}
    1695. 

  1695.           */
    1696. 

  1696.          IS_OPERATORS:IS_OPERATORS,
    1697. 

  1697.          /**
    1698. 

  1698.           * Default two arity operators.
    1699. 

  1699.           *
    1700. 

  1700.           * @type Object
    1701. 

  1701.           * @default {
    1702. 

  1702.           *      EQ:'=',
    1703. 

  1703.           *      NEQ:'!=', LIKE:"LIKE",
    1704. 

  1704.           *      "NOT LIKE":'NOT LIKE',
    1705. 

  1705.           *      ILIKE:"ILIKE",
    1706. 

  1706.           *      "NOT ILIKE":'NOT ILIKE',
    1707. 

  1707.           *      "~":"~",
    1708. 

  1708.           *      '!~':"!~",
    1709. 

  1709.           *      '~*':"~*",
    1710. 

  1710.           *      '!~*':"!~*",
    1711. 

  1711.           *      GT:">",
    1712. 

  1712.           *      GTE:">=",
    1713. 

  1713.           *      LT:"<",
    1714. 

  1714.           *      LTE:"<=",
    1715. 

  1715.           *      bitWiseAnd:"&",
    1716. 

  1716.           *      bitWiseOr:"|",
    1717. 

  1717.           *      exclusiveOr:"^",
    1718. 

  1718.           *      leftShift:"<<",
    1719. 

  1719.           *      rightShift:">>",
    1720. 

  1720.           *      IS:"IS",
    1721. 

  1721.           *      ISNOT:'IS NOT',
    1722. 

  1722.           *      IN:"IN",
    1723. 

  1723.           *      NOTIN:'NOT IN'
    1724. 

  1724.           *  }
    1725. 

  1725.           */
    1726. 

  1726.          TWO_ARITY_OPERATORS:TWO_ARITY_OPERATORS,
    1727. 

  1727.  
    1728. 

  1728.          /**
    1729. 

  1729.           * Default N(multi) arity operators.
    1730. 

  1730.           *
    1731. 

  1731.           * @type Object
    1732. 

  1732.           * @default {
    1733. 

  1733.           *      "||":"||",
    1734. 

  1734.           *      AND:"AND",
    1735. 

  1735.           *      OR:"OR",
    1736. 

  1736.           *      PLUS:"+",
    1737. 

  1737.           *      MINUS:"-",
    1738. 

  1738.           *      DIVIDE:"/", MULTIPLY:"*"
    1739. 

  1739.           * }
    1740. 

  1740.           */
    1741. 

  1741.          N_ARITY_OPERATORS:N_ARITY_OPERATORS,
    1742. 

  1742.  
    1743. 

  1743.          /**
    1744. 

  1744.           * Default ONE operators.
    1745. 

  1745.           *
    1746. 

  1746.           * @type Object
    1747. 

  1747.           * @default {
    1748. 

  1748.           *      "NOT":"NOT",
    1749. 

  1749.           *      "NOOP":"NOOP"
    1750. 

  1750.           *  }
    1751. 

  1751.           */
    1752. 

  1752.          ONE_ARITY_OPERATORS:ONE_ARITY_OPERATORS
    1753. 

  1753.      }
    1754. 

  1754.  }).as(sql, "ComplexExpression");
    1755. 

  1755.  
    1756. 

  1756.  
    1757. 

  1757.  /**
    1758. 

  1758.   * @class Subclass of {@link patio.sql.ComplexExpression} where the expression results
    1759. 

  1759.   * in a boolean value in SQL.
    1760. 

  1760.   *
    1761. 

  1761.   * @augments patio.sql.ComplexExpression
    1762. 

  1762.   * @augments patio.sql.BooleanMethods
    1763. 

  1763.   * @name BooleanExpression
    1764. 

  1764.   * @memberOf patio.sql
    1765. 

  1765.   */
    1766. 

  1766. 1var BooleanExpression = define([ComplexExpression, BooleanMethods], {
    1767. 

  1767.      static:{
    1768. 

  1768.          /**@lends patio.sql.BooleanExpression*/
    1769. 

  1769.  
    1770. 

  1770.          /**
    1771. 

  1771.           * Invert the expression, if possible.  If the expression cannot
    1772. 

  1772.           * be inverted, it throws an {@link patio.error.ExpressionError}.  An inverted expression should match
    1773. 

  1773.           * everything that the uninverted expression did not match, and vice-versa, except for possible issues with
    1774. 

  1774.           * SQL NULL (i.e. 1 == NULL is NULL and 1 != NULL is also NULL).
    1775. 

  1775.           *
    1776. 

  1776.           * @example
    1777. 

  1777.           *   BooleanExpression.invert(sql.a) //=> NOT "a"
    1778. 

  1778.           *
    1779. 

  1779.           * @param {patio.sql.BooleanExpression} expression
    1780. 

  1780.           * the expression to invert.
    1781. 

  1781.           *
    1782. 

  1782.           * @return {patio.sql.BooleanExpression} the inverted expression.
    1783. 

  1783.           */
    1784. 

  1784.          invert:function (expression) {
    1785. 

  1785. 95            if (isInstanceOf(expression, BooleanExpression)) {
    1786. 

  1786. 90                var op = expression.op, newArgs;
    1787. 

  1787. 90                if (op == "AND" || op == "OR") {
    1788. 

  1788. 3                    newArgs = [OPERTATOR_INVERSIONS[op]].concat(expression.args.map(function (arg) {
    1789. 

  1789. 6                        return BooleanExpression.invert(arg);
    1790. 

  1790.                      }));
    1791. 

  1791. 3                    return BooleanExpression.fromArgs(newArgs);
    1792. 

  1792.                  } else {
    1793. 

  1793. 87                    newArgs = [OPERTATOR_INVERSIONS[op]].concat(expression.args);
    1794. 

  1794. 87                    return BooleanExpression.fromArgs(newArgs);
    1795. 

  1795.                  }
    1796. 

  1796. 5            } else if (isInstanceOf(expression, StringExpression) || isInstanceOf(expression, NumericExpression)) {
    1797. 

  1797. 0                throw new ExpressionError(format("Cannot invert %4j", [expression]));
    1798. 

  1798.              } else {
    1799. 

  1799. 5                return new BooleanExpression("NOT", expression);
    1800. 

  1800.              }
    1801. 

  1801.          },
    1802. 

  1802.          /**
    1803. 

  1803.           * Take pairs of values (e.g. a hash or array of two element arrays)
    1804. 

  1804.           * and converts it to a {@link patio.sql.BooleanExpression}.  The operator and args
    1805. 

  1805.           * used depends on the case of the right (2nd) argument:
    1806. 

  1806.           *
    1807. 

  1807.           * <pre class='code'>
    1808. 

  1808.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : [1,2,3]}) //=> a IN (1,2,3)
    1809. 

  1809.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : true}); // a IS TRUE;
    1810. 

  1810.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : /^A/i}); // a *~ '^A'
    1811. 

  1811.           * </pre>
    1812. 

  1812.           *
    1813. 

  1813.           * If multiple arguments are given, they are joined with the op given (AND
    1814. 

  1814.           * by default, OR possible).  If negate is set to true,
    1815. 

  1815.           * all subexpressions are inverted before used.
    1816. 

  1816.           * <pre class='code'>
    1817. 

  1817.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : [1,2,3], b : true}) //=> a IN (1,2,3) AND b IS TRUE
    1818. 

  1818.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : [1,2,3], b : true}, "OR") //=> a IN (1,2,3) OR b IS TRUE
    1819. 

  1819.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : [1,2,3], b : true}, "OR", true) //=> a NOT IN (1,2,3) AND b IS NOT TRUE
    1820. 

  1820.           * </pre>
    1821. 

  1821.           * @param {Object} a object to convert to a {@link patio.sql.BooleanExpression}
    1822. 

  1822.           * @param {String} [op="AND"] Boolean operator to join each subexpression with.
    1823. 

  1823.           * <pre class="code">
    1824. 

  1824.           *     BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : [1,2,3], b : true}, "OR") //=> a IN (1,2,3) OR b IS TRUE
    1825. 

  1825.           * </pre>
    1826. 

  1826.           * @param {Boolean} [negate=false] set to try to invert the {@link patio.sql.BooleanExpression}.
    1827. 

  1827.           * <pre class="code">
    1828. 

  1828.           * BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs({a : [1,2,3], b : true}, "OR", true) //=> a NOT IN (1,2,3) AND b IS NOT TRUE
    1829. 

  1829.           * </pre>
    1830. 

  1830.           * @return {patio.sql.BooleanExpression} expression composed of sub expressions built from the hash.
    1831. 

  1831.           */
    1832. 

  1832.          fromValuePairs:function (a, op, negate) {
    1833. 

  1833. 7677            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    1834. 

  1834. 7677            op = op || "AND", negate = negate || false;
    1835. 

  1835. 7677            var pairArr = [];
    1836. 

  1836. 7677            var isArr = isArray(a) && Expression.isConditionSpecifier(a);
    1837. 

  1837. 7677            if (isHash(a)) {
    1838. 

  1838. 3434                pairArr.push(this.__filterObject(a));
    1839. 

  1839.              } else {
    1840. 

  1840. 4243                for (var k in a) {
    1841. 

  1841. 5058                    var v = isArr ? a[k][1] : a[k], ret;
    1842. 

  1842. 5058                    k = isArr ? a[k][0] : k;
    1843. 

  1843. 5058                    if (isArray(v) || isInstanceOf(v, Dataset)) {
    1844. 

  1844. 17                        k = isArray(k) ? k.map(function (i) {
    1845. 

  1845. 12                            return isString(i) ? sql.stringToIdentifier(i) : i
    1846. 

  1846.                          }) : isString(k) ? sql.stringToIdentifier(k) : k;
    1847. 

  1847. 17                        ret = new BooleanExpression("IN", k, v);
    1848. 

  1848. 5041                    } else if (isInstanceOf(v, NegativeBooleanConstant)) {
    1849. 

  1849. 0                        ret = new BooleanExpression("ISNOT", k, v.constant);
    1850. 

  1850. 5041                    } else if (isInstanceOf(v, BooleanConstant)) {
    1851. 

  1851. 0                        ret = new BooleanExpression("IS", k, v.constant);
    1852. 

  1852. 5041                    } else if (isNull(v) || isBoolean(v)) {
    1853. 

  1853. 207                        ret = new BooleanExpression("IS", k, v);
    1854. 

  1854. 4834                    } else if (isHash(v)) {
    1855. 

  1855. 0                        ret = BooleanExpression.__filterObject(v, k);
    1856. 

  1856. 4834                    } else if (isRegExp(v)) {
    1857. 

  1857. 69                        ret = StringExpression.like(sql.stringToIdentifier(k), v);
    1858. 

  1858.                      } else {
    1859. 

  1859. 4765                        ret = new BooleanExpression("EQ", sql.stringToIdentifier(k), v);
    1860. 

  1860.                      }
    1861. 

  1861. 5058                    negate && (ret = BooleanExpression.invert(ret));
    1862. 

  1862. 5058                    pairArr.push(ret);
    1863. 

  1863.                  }
    1864. 

  1864.              }
    1865. 

  1865.              //if We just have one then return the first otherwise create a new Boolean expression
    1866. 

  1866. 7677            return pairArr.length == 1 ? pairArr[0] : BooleanExpression.fromArgs([op].concat(pairArr));
    1867. 

  1867.          },
    1868. 

  1868.  
    1869. 

  1869.          /**
    1870. 

  1870.           * @private
    1871. 

  1871.           *
    1872. 

  1872.           * This builds an expression from a hash
    1873. 

  1873.           *
    1874. 

  1874.           * @example
    1875. 

  1875.           *
    1876. 

  1876.           *  Dataset._filterObject({a : 1}) //=> WHERE (a = 1)
    1877. 

  1877.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {gt : 1}}) //=> WHERE (x > 1)
    1878. 

  1878.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {gt : 1}, a : 1}) //=> WHERE ((x > 1) AND (a = 1))
    1879. 

  1879.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {like : "name"}}) //=> WHERE (x LIKE 'name')
    1880. 

  1880.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {iLike : "name"}}) //=> WHERE (x LIKE 'name')
    1881. 

  1881.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {between : [1,10]}}) //=> WHERE ((x >= 1) AND (x <= 10))
    1882. 

  1882.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {notBetween : [1,10]}}) //=> WHERE ((x < 1) OR (x > 10))
    1883. 

  1883.           *  Dataset._filterObject({x : {neq : 1}}) //=> WHERE (x != 1)
    1884. 

  1884.           *
    1885. 

  1885.           * @param {Object} expr the expression we need to create an expression out of
    1886. 

  1886.           * @param {String} [key=null] the key that the hash corresponds to
    1887. 

  1887.           *
    1888. 

  1888.           * @return {patio.sql.Expression} an expression to use in the filter
    1889. 

  1889.           */
    1890. 

  1890.          __filterObject:function (expr, key) {
    1891. 

  1891. 3551            var pairs = [], opts, newKey;
    1892. 

  1892. 3551            var twoArityOperators = this.TWO_ARITY_OPERATORS;
    1893. 

  1893. 3551            for (var k in expr) {
    1894. 

  1894. 3590                var v = expr[k];
    1895. 

  1895. 3590                if (isHash(v)) { //its a hash too filter it too!
    1896. 

  1896. 115                    pairs.push(this.__filterObject(v, k));
    1897. 

  1897. 3475                } else if (key && (twoArityOperators[k.toUpperCase()] || k.match(/between/i))) {
    1898. 

  1898.                      //its a two arrity operator (e.g. '=', '>')
    1899. 

  1899. 118                    newKey = isString(key) ? key.split(",") : [key];
    1900. 

  1900. 118                    if (newKey.length > 1) {
    1901. 

  1901.                          //this represents a hash where the key represents two columns
    1902. 

  1902.                          //(e.g. {"col1,col2" : 1}) => WHERE (col1 = 1 AND col2 = 1)
    1903. 

  1903. 1                        pairs = pairs.concat(newKey.map(function (k) {
    1904. 

  1904.                              //filter each column with the expression
    1905. 

  1905. 2                            return this.__filterObject(expr, k);
    1906. 

  1906.                          }, this));
    1907. 

  1907.                      } else {
    1908. 

  1908. 117                        newKey = [sql.stringToIdentifier(newKey[0])];
    1909. 

  1909. 117                        if (k.match(/^like$/)) {
    1910. 

  1910.                              //its a like clause {col : {like : "hello"}}
    1911. 

  1911.  
    1912. 

  1912. 3                            pairs.push(StringExpression.like.apply(StringExpression, (newKey.concat(isArray(v) ? v : [v]))));
    1913. 

  1913. 114                        } else if (k.match(/^iLike$/)) {
    1914. 

  1914.                              //its a like clause {col : {iLike : "hello"}}
    1915. 

  1915. 2                            pairs.push(StringExpression.like.apply(StringExpression, (newKey.concat(isArray(v) ? v : [v]).concat({caseInsensitive:true}))));
    1916. 

  1916. 112                        } else if (k.match(/between/i)) {
    1917. 

  1917.                              //its a like clause {col : {between : [1,10]}}
    1918. 

  1918. 6                            var between = sql.stringToIdentifier(newKey[0]).between(v);
    1919. 

  1919. 6                            k == "notBetween" && (between = between.not());
    1920. 

  1920. 6                            pairs.push(between);
    1921. 

  1921.                          } else {
    1922. 

  1922.                              //otherwise is just a boolean expressio
    1923. 

  1923.                              //it its not a valid operator then we
    1924. 

  1924.                              //BooleanExpression with throw an error
    1925. 

  1925. 106                            pairs.push(new BooleanExpression(k, newKey[0], v));
    1926. 

  1926.                          }
    1927. 

  1927.                      }
    1928. 

  1928.                  } else {
    1929. 

  1929.                      //we're not a twoarity operator
    1930. 

  1930.                      //so we create a boolean expression out of it
    1931. 

  1931. 3357                    newKey = k.split(",");
    1932. 

  1932. 3357                    if (newKey.length == 1) {
    1933. 

  1933. 3351                        newKey = sql.stringToIdentifier(newKey[0]);
    1934. 

  1934.                      }
    1935. 

  1935. 3357                    opts = [
    1936. 

  1936.                          [newKey, v]
    1937. 

  1937.                      ];
    1938. 

  1938. 3357                    pairs.push(BooleanExpression.fromValuePairs(opts));
    1939. 

  1939.                  }
    1940. 

  1940.              }
    1941. 

  1941.              //if the total of pairs is one then we just return the first element
    1942. 

  1942.              //otherwise we join them all with an AND
    1943. 

  1943. 3551            return pairs.length == 1 ? pairs[0] : BooleanExpression.fromArgs(["AND"].concat(pairs));
    1944. 

  1944.          }
    1945. 

  1945.      }
    1946. 

  1946.  }).as(sql, "BooleanExpression");
    1947. 

  1947.  
    1948. 

  1948.  
    1949. 

  1949. 1var Constant = define(GenericExpression, {
    1950. 

  1950.      instance:{
    1951. 

  1951.          /**@lends patio.sql.Constant.prototype*/
    1952. 

  1952.          /**
    1953. 

  1953.           * Represents constants or psuedo-constants (e.g.'CURRENT_DATE) in SQL.
    1954. 

  1954.           *
    1955. 

  1955.           * @constructs
    1956. 

  1956.           * @augments patio.sql.GenericExpression
    1957. 

  1957.           * @property {String} constant <b>READ ONLY</b> the contant.
    1958. 

  1958.           */
    1959. 

  1959.          constructor:function (constant) {
    1960. 

  1960. 18            this.__constant = constant;
    1961. 

  1961.          },
    1962. 

  1962.  
    1963. 

  1963.          /**
    1964. 

  1964.           * Converts the {@link patio.sql.Constant} to a string.
    1965. 

  1965.           *
    1966. 

  1966.           * @param {patio.Dataset} [ds] dataset used to created the SQL fragment, if
    1967. 

  1967.           * the dataset is ommited then the default {@link patio.Dataset} implementation is used.
    1968. 

  1968.           *
    1969. 

  1969.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.Constant}.
    1970. 

  1970.           */
    1971. 

  1971.          toString:function (ds) {
    1972. 

  1972. 6            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    1973. 

  1973. 6            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    1974. 

  1974. 6            return ds.constantSql(this.__constant);
    1975. 

  1975.          },
    1976. 

  1976.  
    1977. 

  1977.          getters:{
    1978. 

  1978.              constant:function () {
    1979. 

  1979. 0                return this.__constant;
    1980. 

  1980.              }
    1981. 

  1981.          }
    1982. 

  1982.      }
    1983. 

  1983.  }).as(sql, "Constant");
    1984. 

  1984.  
    1985. 

  1985.  /**
    1986. 

  1986.   * @class Represents boolean constants such as NULL, NOTNULL, TRUE, and FALSE.
    1987. 

  1987.   * @auments patio.sql.Constant
    1988. 

  1988.   * @name BooleanConstant
    1989. 

  1989.   * @memberOf patio.sql
    1990. 

  1990.   */
    1991. 

  1991. 1var BooleanConstant = define(Constant, {
    1992. 

  1992.      instance:{
    1993. 

  1993.          /**@lends patio.sql.BooleanConstant.prototype*/
    1994. 

  1994.  
    1995. 

  1995.          /**
    1996. 

  1996.           * Converts the {@link patio.sql.BooleanConstant} to a string.
    1997. 

  1997.           *
    1998. 

  1998.           * @param {patio.Dataset} [ds] dataset used to created the SQL fragment, if
    1999. 

  1999.           * the dataset is ommited then the default {@link patio.Dataset} implementation is used.
    2000. 

  2000.           *
    2001. 

  2001.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.BooleanConstant}.
    2002. 

  2002.           */
    2003. 

  2003.          toString:function (ds) {
    2004. 

  2004. 10            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    2005. 

  2005. 10            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    2006. 

  2006. 10            return ds.booleanConstantSql(this.__constant);
    2007. 

  2007.          }
    2008. 

  2008.      }
    2009. 

  2009.  }).as(sql, "BooleanConstant");
    2010. 

  2010.  
    2011. 

  2011.  /**
    2012. 

  2012.   * Represents inverse boolean constants (currently only NOTNULL). A
    2013. 

  2013.   * special class to allow for special behavior.
    2014. 

  2014.   *
    2015. 

  2015.   * @augments patio.sql.BooleanConstant
    2016. 

  2016.   * @name NegativeBooleanConstant
    2017. 

  2017.   * @memberOf patio.sql
    2018. 

  2018.   */
    2019. 

  2019. 1var NegativeBooleanConstant = define(BooleanConstant, {
    2020. 

  2020.      instance:{
    2021. 

  2021.          /**@lends patio.sql.NegativeBooleanConstant.prototype*/
    2022. 

  2022.  
    2023. 

  2023.          /**
    2024. 

  2024.           * Converts the {@link patio.sql.NegativeBooleanConstant} to a string.
    2025. 

  2025.           *
    2026. 

  2026.           * @param {patio.Dataset} [ds] dataset used to created the SQL fragment, if
    2027. 

  2027.           * the dataset is ommited then the default {@link patio.Dataset} implementation is used.
    2028. 

  2028.           *
    2029. 

  2029.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.NegativeBooleanConstant}.
    2030. 

  2030.           */
    2031. 

  2031.          toString:function (ds) {
    2032. 

  2032. 2            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    2033. 

  2033. 2            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    2034. 

  2034. 2            return ds.negativeBooleanConstantSql(this.__constant);
    2035. 

  2035.          }
    2036. 

  2036.      }
    2037. 

  2037.  }).as(sql, "NegativeBooleanConstant");
    2038. 

  2038.

  2105. 1var Identifier = define([GenericExpression, QualifyingMethods], {
    2106. 

  2106.      instance:{
    2107. 

  2107.          /**@lends patio.sql.Identifier.prototype*/
    2108. 

  2108.  
    2109. 

  2109.          /**
    2110. 

  2110.           * Represents an identifier (column or table). Can be used
    2111. 

  2111.           * to specify a String with multiple underscores that should not be
    2112. 

  2112.           * split, or for creating an implicit identifier without using a String.
    2113. 

  2113.           *
    2114. 

  2114.           * @constructs
    2115. 

  2115.           * @augments patio.sql.GenericExpression
    2116.

    2117.

    2119. 

  2119.           *
    2120. 

  2120.           * @property {String} value <b>READ ONLY</b> the column or table this identifier represents.
    2121. 

  2121.           */
    2122. 

  2122.          constructor:function (value) {
    2123. 

  2123. 16682            this.__value = value;
    2124. 

  2124.          },
    2125. 

  2125.  
    2126. 

  2126.          /**
    2127. 

  2127.           * Converts the {@link patio.sql.Identifier} to a string.
    2128.

    2129. 

  2129.           * @param {patio.Dataset} [ds] dataset used to created the SQL fragment, if
    2130.

    2131. 

  2131.           *
    2132. 

  2132.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.Identifier}.
    2133. 

  2133.           */
    2134. 

  2134.          toString:function (ds) {
    2135. 

  2135. 22008            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    2136. 

  2136. 22008            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    2137. 

  2137. 22008            return ds.quoteIdentifier(this);
    2138. 

  2138.          },
    2139.

  2292. 1var PlaceHolderLiteralString = define(GenericExpression, {
    2293. 

  2293.      instance:{
    2294. 

  2294.          /**@lends patio.sql.PlaceHolderLiteralString.prototype*/
    2295. 

  2295.  
    2296. 

  2296.          /**
    2297. 

  2297.           * Represents a literal string with placeholders and arguments.
    2298. 

  2298.           * This is necessary to ensure delayed literalization of the arguments
    2299. 

  2299.           * required for the prepared statement support and for database-specific
    2300. 

  2300.           * literalization.
    2301. 

  2301.           *
    2302. 

  2302.           * @constructs
    2303. 

  2303.           * @augments patio.sql.GenericExpression
    2304. 

  2304.           *
    2305. 

  2305.           * @param {String} str the string that contains placeholders.
    2306. 

  2306.           * @param {Array} args array of arguments that will be literalized using {@link patio.Dataset#literal}, and
    2307. 

  2307.           * replaced in the string.
    2308. 

  2308.           * @param {Boolean} [parens=false] set to true to wrap the string in parens.
    2309. 

  2309.           *
    2310. 

  2310.           * @property {String} str <b>READ ONLY</b> the string that contains placeholders.
    2311. 

  2311.           * @property {Array} args <b>READ ONLY</b> array of arguments that will be literalized using {@link patio.Dataset#literal}, and
    2312. 

  2312.           * replaced in the string.
    2313. 

  2313.           * @property {String} parens <b>READ ONLY</b> set to true to wrap the string in parens.
    2314. 

  2314.           */
    2315. 

  2315.          constructor:function (str, args, parens) {
    2316. 

  2316. 55            parens = parens || false;
    2317. 

  2317. 55            var v;
    2318. 

  2318. 55            this.__str = str;
    2319. 

  2319. 55            this.__args = isArray(args) && args.length == 1 && isHash((v = args[0])) ? v : args;
    2320. 

  2320. 55            this.__parens = parens;
    2321. 

  2321.          },
    2322. 

  2322.  
    2323. 

  2323.          /**
    2324. 

  2324.           * Converts the {@link patio.sql.PlaceHolderLiteralString} to a string.

    2327. 

  2327.           * the dataset is ommited then the default {@link patio.Dataset} implementation is used.

  2328.           *
    2329. 

  2329.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.PlaceHolderLiteralString}.
    2330. 

  2330.           */
    2331. 

  2331.          toString:function (ds) {
    2332. 

  2332. 55            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    2333. 

  2333. 55            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    2334. 

  2334. 55            return ds.placeholderLiteralStringSql(this);
    2335. 

  2335.          },
    2336. 

  2336.  
    2337. 

  2337.          /**@ignore*/
    2338. 

  2338.          getters:{

  2339.              str:function () {
    2340. 

  2340. 58                return this.__str;
    2341. 

  2341.              },
    2342.

    2343. 

  2343. 58                return this.__args;
    2344. 

  2344.              },

  2355. 1var SQLFunction = define(GenericExpression, {
    2356. 

  2356.      instance:{
    2357. 

  2357.          /**@lends patio.sql.SQLFunction.prototype*/
    2358. 

  2358.  
    2359. 

  2359.          /**
    2360. 

  2360.           * Represents an SQL function call.
    2361. 

  2361.           *
    2362. 

  2362.           * @constructs
    2363. 

  2363.           * @augments patio.sql.GenericExpression
    2364. 

  2364.           *
    2365. 

  2365.           * @param {...} f variable number of arguments where the first argument is the name
    2366. 

  2366.           * of the SQL function to invoke. The rest of the arguments will be literalized through
    2367. 

  2367.           * {@link patio.Dataset#literal} and placed into the SQL function call.
    2368. 

  2368.           *
    2369. 

  2369.           * @property {String} f <b>READ ONLY</b> the SQL function to call.
    2370. 

  2370.           * @property {Array} args <b>READ ONLY</b> args  arguments will be literalized through
    2371. 

  2371.           * {@link patio.Dataset#literal} and placed into the SQL function call.
    2372. 

  2372.           * */
    2373. 

  2373.          constructor:function (f) {
    2374. 

  2374. 1109            var args = argsToArray(arguments).slice(1);
    2375. 

  2375. 1109            this.__f = isInstanceOf(f, Identifier) ? f.value : f, this.__args = args.map(function (a) {
    2376. 

  2376. 773                return isString(a) ? sql.stringToIdentifier(a) : a;
    2377. 

  2377.              });
    2378. 

  2378.          },
    2379. 

  2379.  
    2380. 

  2380.          /**
    2381. 

  2381.           * Converts the {@link patio.sql.SQLFunction} to a string.
    2382. 

  2382.           *
    2383. 

  2383.           * @param {patio.Dataset} [ds] dataset used to created the SQL fragment, if
    2384. 

  2384.           * the dataset is ommited then the default {@link patio.Dataset} implementation is used.
    2385. 

  2385.           *
    2386. 

  2386.           * @return String the SQL version of the {@link patio.sql.SQLFunction}.
    2387. 

  2387.           */
    2388. 

  2388.          toString:function (ds) {
    2389. 

  2389. 565            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("./dataset"));
    2390. 

  2390. 565            ds = ds || new Dataset();
    2391. 

  2391. 565            return ds.functionSql(this);
    2392. 

  2392.          },
    2393. 

  2393.  
    2394. 

  2394.          /**@ignore*/
    2395. 

  2395.          getters:{
    2396. 

  2396.              f:function () {
    2397. 

  2397. 567                return this.__f;
    2398. 

  2398.              },
    2399. 

  2399.  
    2400. 

  2400.              args:function () {
    2401. 

  2401. 567                return this.__args;
    2402. 

  2402.              }
    2403. 

  2403.          }
    2404. 

  2404.      }
    2405. 

  2405.  }).as(sql, "SQLFunction");
    2406. 

  2406.  
    2407. 

  2407.  /**
    2408. 

  2408.   * @class Subclass of {@link patio.sql.ComplexExpression} where the expression results
    2409.

    2410. 

  2410.   *

  2411.   * @name NumericExpression
    2412.

    2416.

    2417. 

  2417.   */
    2418. 

  2418. 1var NumericExpression = define([ComplexExpression, BitWiseMethods, NumericMethods, InequalityMethods]).as(sql, "NumericExpression");
    2419. 

  2419.  
    2420. 

  2420.  
    2421. 

  2421. 1var OrderedExpression = define(Expression, {
    2422. 

  2422.      instance:{
    2423. 

  2423.          /**@lends patio.sql.OrderedExpression.prototype*/
    2424. 

  2424.  
    2425. 

  2425.          /**
    2426. 

  2426.           * Represents a column/expression to order the result set by.
    2427. 

  2427.           * @constructs
    2428. 

  2428.           * @augments patio.sql.Expression
    2429. 

  2429.           *
    2430. 

  2430.           * @param expression the expression to order
    2431. 

  2431.           * @param {Boolean}[descending=true] set to false to order ASC
    2432. 

  2432.           * @param {String|Object} [opts=null] additional options
    2433. 

  2433.           * <ul>
    2434. 

  2434.           *     <li>String: if value is "first" the null values will be first, if "last" then null values
    2435. 

  2435.           *     will be last</li>
    2436. 

  2436.           *     <li>Object: will pull the nulls property off of the object use use the same rules as if it
    2437. 

  2437.           *     were a string</li>
    2438. 

  2438.           * </ul>
    2439. 

  2439.           * @property expression <b>READ ONLY</b> the expression to order.
    2440. 

  2440.           * @property {Boolean} [descending=true] <b>READ ONLY</b> true if decending, false otherwise.
    2441. 

  2441.           * @property {String} [nulls=null] if value is "first" the null values will be first, if "last" then null values
    2442. 

  2442.           *     will be last
    2443. 

  2443.           */
    2444. 

  2444.          constructor:function (expression, descending, opts) {
    2445. 

  2445. 92            descending = isBoolean(descending) ? descending : true;
    2446. 

  2446. 92            opts = opts || {};
    2447. 

  2447. 92            this.__expression = expression;
    2448. 

  2448. 92            this.__descending = descending;
    2449. 

  2449. 92            var nulls = isString(opts) ? opts : opts.nulls;
    2450. 

  2450. 92            this.__nulls = isString(nulls) ? nulls.toLowerCase() : null;
    2451. 

  2451.          },
    2452. 

  2452.  
    2453. 

  2453.          /**
    2454. 

  2454.           * @return {patio.sql.OrderedExpression} a copy that is ordered ASC
    2455. 

  2455.           */
    2456. 

  2456.          asc:function () {
    2457. 

  2457. 0            return new OrderedExpression(this.__expression, false, {nulls:this.__nulls});
    2458. 

  2458.          },
    2459. 

  2459.  
    2460. 

  2460.          /**

  2463.          desc:function () {
    2464. 

  2464. 0            return new OrderedExpression(this.__expression, true, {nulls:this.__nulls});
    2465.

    2466. 

  2466.  
    2467. 

  2467.          /**

    2469.

  2470.          invert:function () {

    2472. 

  2472.          },
    2473. 

  2473.  
    2474.

  2562. 1var likeElement = function (re) {
    2563. 

  2563. 875    var ret;
    2564. 

  2564. 875    if (isRegExp(re)) {
    2565. 

  2565. 80        ret = [("" + re).replace(/^\/|\/$|\/[i|m|g]*$/g, ""), true, re.ignoreCase]
    2566. 

  2566.      } else {
    2567. 

  2567. 795        ret = [re, false, false];
    2568. 

  2568.      }
    2569. 

  2569. 875    return ret;
    2570. 

  2570.  };
    2571. 

  2571.  /**
    2572. 

  2572.   * @class Subclass of {@link patio.sql.ComplexExpression} where the expression results
    2573. 

  2573.   * in a text/string/varchar value in SQL.
    2574. 

  2574.   *
    2575. 

  2575.   * @augments patio.sql.ComplexExpression
    2576. 

  2576.   * @augments patio.sql.StringMethods
    2577. 

  2577.   * @augments patio.sql.StringConcatenationMethods
    2578. 

  2578.   * @augments patio.sql.InequalityMethods
    2579. 

  2579.   * @augments patio.sql.NoBooleanInputMethods
    2580. 

  2580.   * @name StringExpression
    2581. 

  2581.   * @memberOf patio.sql
    2582. 

  2582.   */
    2583. 

  2583. 1var StringExpression = define([ComplexExpression, StringMethods, StringConcatenationMethods, InequalityMethods, NoBooleanInputMethods], {
    2584. 

  2584.      static:{
    2585. 

  2585.          /**@lends patio.sql.StringExpression*/
    2586. 

  2586.  
    2587. 

  2587.          /**
    2588. 

  2588.           * <p>Creates a SQL pattern match expression. left (l) is the SQL string we
    2589. 

  2589.           * are matching against, and ces are the patterns we are matching.
    2590. 

  2590.           * The match succeeds if any of the patterns match (SQL OR).</p>
    2591. 

  2591.           *
    2592. 

  2592.           * <p>If a regular expression is used as a pattern, an SQL regular expression will be
    2593. 

  2593.           * used, which is currently only supported on MySQL and PostgreSQL.  Be aware
    2594. 

  2594.           * that MySQL and PostgreSQL regular expression syntax is similar to javascript
    2595. 

  2595.           * regular expression syntax, but it not exactly the same, especially for
    2596. 

  2596.           * advanced regular expression features.  Patio just uses the source of the
    2597. 

  2597.           * regular expression verbatim as the SQL regular expression string.</p>
    2598. 

  2598.           *
    2599. 

  2599.           * <p>If any other object is used as a regular expression, the SQL LIKE operator will
    2600. 

  2600.           * be used, and should be supported by most databases.</p>
    2601. 

  2601.           *
    2602. 

  2602.           * <p>The pattern match will be case insensitive if the last argument is a hash
    2603. 

  2603.           * with a key of caseInsensitive that is not false or null. Also,
    2604. 

  2604.           * if a case insensitive regular expression is used (//i), that particular
    2605. 

  2605.           * pattern which will always be case insensitive.</p>
    2606. 

  2606.           *
    2607. 

  2607.           * @example
    2608. 

  2608.           *   StringExpression.like(sql.a, 'a%') //=> "a" LIKE 'a%'
    2609. 

  2609.           *   StringExpression.like(sql.a, 'a%', {caseInsensitive : true}) //=> "a" ILIKE 'a%'
    2610. 

  2610.           *   StringExpression.like(sql.a, 'a%', /^a/i) //=> "a" LIKE 'a%' OR "a" ~* '^a'
    2611. 

  2611.           */
    2612. 

  2612.          like:function (l) {
    2613. 

  2613. 437            var args = argsToArray(arguments, 1);
    2614. 

  2614. 437            var params = likeElement(l);
    2615. 

  2615. 437            var likeMap = this.likeMap;
    2616. 

  2616. 437            var lh = params[0], lre = params[1], lci = params[2];
    2617. 

  2617. 437            var last = args[args.length - 1];
    2618. 

  2618. 437            lci = (isHash(last) ? args.pop() : {})["caseInsensitive"] ? true : lci;
    2619. 

  2619. 437            args = args.map(function (ce) {
    2620. 

  2620. 438                var r, rre, rci;
    2621. 

  2621. 438                var ceArr = likeElement(ce);
    2622. 

  2622. 438                r = ceArr[0], rre = ceArr[1], rci = ceArr[2];
    2623. 

  2623. 438                return new BooleanExpression(likeMap["" + (lre || rre) + (lci || rci)], l, r)
    2624. 

  2624.              }, this);
    2625. 

  2625. 437            return args.length == 1 ? args[0] : BooleanExpression.fromArgs(["OR"].concat(args));
    2626. 

  2626.          },
    2627. 

  2627.  
    2628. 

  2628.          /**
    2629. 

  2629.           * Like map used to by {@link patio.sql.StringExpression.like} to create the
    2630. 

  2630.           * LIKE expression.
    2631. 

  2631.           * @type Object
    2632. 

  2632.           */
    2633. 

  2633.          likeMap:{"truetrue":'~*', "truefalse":"~", "falsetrue":"ILIKE", "falsefalse":"LIKE"}
    2634. 

  2634.  
    2635. 

  2635.  
    2636. 

  2636.      }
    2637. 

  2637.  }).as(sql, "StringExpression");
    2638. 

  2638.  
    2639.

  24. 1var Database = define(null, {
    25. 

  25.      instance:{
    26. 

  26.          /**@lends patio.Database.prototype*/
    27. 

  27.  
    28. 

  28.          /**
    29. 

  29.           * The method name to invoke on a connection. The method name
    30. 

  30.           * should be overrode by an adapter if the method to execute
    31. 

  31.           * a query is different for the adapter specific connection class.
    32. 

  32.           */
    33. 

  33.          connectionExecuteMethod:"execute",
    34. 

  34.  
    35. 

  35.          /**
    36. 

  36.           * The <b>BEGIN</b> SQL fragment used to signify the start of a transaciton.
    37.
