    76. 

  76.  
    77. 

  77.          /**
    78. 

  78.           * Adds a RETURNING clause, which is not supported by all databases. If returning is
    79. 

  79.           * used instead of returning the autogenerated primary key or update/delete returning the number of rows modified.
    80. 

  80.           *
    81. 

  81.           * @example
    82. 

  82.           *
    83. 

  83.           * ds.from("items").returning() //"RETURNING *"
    84. 

  84.           * ds.from("items").returning(null) //"RETURNING NULL"
    85. 

  85.           * ds.from("items").returning("id", "name") //"RETURNING id, name"
    86. 

  86.           * ds.from("items").returning(["id", "name"]) //"RETURNING id, name"
    87. 

  87.           *
    88. 

  88.           * @param values columns to return. If values is an array then the array is assumed to contain the columns to
    89. 

  89.           * return. Otherwise the arguments will be used.
    90. 

  90.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a new dataset with the retuning option added.
    91. 

  91.           */
    92. 

  92.          returning:function (values) {
    93. 

  93. 1314            var args;
    94. 

  94. 1314            if (Array.isArray(values)) {
    95. 

  95. 0                args = values;
    96. 

  96.              } else {
    97. 

  97. 1314                args = argsToArray(arguments);
    98. 

  98.              }
    99. 

  99. 1314            return this.mergeOptions({returning:args.map(function (v) {
    100. 

  100. 1148                return isString(v) ? sql.stringToIdentifier(v) : v;
    101. 

  101.              })});
    102. 

  102.          },
    103. 

  103.  
    104. 

  104.  
    105. 

  105.          /**
    106. 

  106.           * Adds a futher filter to an existing filter using AND. This method is identical to {@link patio.Dataset#filter}
    107. 

  107.           * except it expects an existing filter.
    108. 

  108.           *
    109. 

  109.           * <p>
    110. 

  110.           *     <b>For parameter types see {@link patio.Dataset#filter}.</b>
    111. 

  111.           * </p>
    112. 

  112.           *
    113. 

  113.           * @example
    114. 

  114.           * DB.from("table").filter("a").and("b").sql;
    115. 

  115.           *      //=>SELECT * FROM table WHERE a AND b
    116. 

  116.           *
    117. 

  117.           * @throws {patio.QueryError} If no WHERE?HAVING clause exists.
    118. 

  118.           *
    119. 

  119.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the condtion added to the WHERE/HAVING clause added.
    120. 

  120.           */
    121. 

  121.          and:function () {
    122. 

  122. 7            var tOpts = this.__opts, clauseObj = tOpts[tOpts.having ? "having" : "where"];
    123. 

  123. 7            if (clauseObj) {
    124. 

  124. 6                return this.filter.apply(this, arguments);
    125. 

  125.              } else {
    126. 

  126. 1                throw new QueryError("No existing filter found");
    127. 

  127.              }
    128. 

  128.          },
    129. 

  129.  
    130. 

  130.          as:function (alias) {
    131. 

  131. 8            return new AliasedExpression(this, alias);
    132. 

  132.          },
    133. 

  133.  
    134. 

  134.          /**
    135. 

  135.           * Adds an alternate filter to an existing WHERE/HAVING using OR.
    136. 

  136.           *
    137. 

  137.           * <p>
    138. 

  138.           *     <b>For parameter types see {@link patio.Dataset#filter}.</b>
    139. 

  139.           * </p>
    140. 

  140.           *
    141. 

  141.           * @example
    142. 

  142.           *
    143. 

  143.           * DB.from("items").filter("a").or("b")
    144. 

  144.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE a OR b
    145. 

  145.           *
    146. 

  146.           * @throws {patio.QueryError} If no WHERE?HAVING clause exists.
    147. 

  147.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the condtion added to the WHERE/HAVING clause added.
    148. 

  148.           */
    149. 

  149.          or:function () {
    150. 

  150. 9            var tOpts = this.__opts;
    151. 

  151. 9            var clause = (tOpts.having ? "having" : "where"), clauseObj = tOpts[clause];
    152. 

  152. 9            if (clauseObj) {
    153. 

  153. 8                var args = argsToArray(arguments);
    154. 

  154. 8                args = args.length == 1 ? args[0] : args;
    155. 

  155. 8                var opts = {};
    156. 

  156. 8                opts[clause] = new BooleanExpression("OR", clauseObj, this._filterExpr(args))
    157. 

  157. 8                return this.mergeOptions(opts);
    158. 

  158.              } else {
    159. 

  159. 1                throw new QueryError("No existing filter found");
    160. 

  160.              }
    161. 

  161.          },
    162. 

  162.  
    163. 

  163.          /**
    164. 

  164.           * Returns a copy of the dataset with the SQL DISTINCT clause.
    165. 

  165.           * The DISTINCT clause is used to remove duplicate rows from the
    166. 

  166.           * output.  If arguments are provided, uses a DISTINCT ON clause,
    167. 

  167.           * in which case it will only be distinct on those columns, instead
    168. 

  168.           * of all returned columns.
    169. 

  169.           *
    170. 

  170.           * @example
    171. 

  171.           *
    172. 

  172.           * DB.from("items").distinct().sqll
    173. 

  173.           *      //=> SELECT DISTINCT * FROM items
    174. 

  174.           * DB.from("items").order("id").distinct("id").sql;
    175. 

  175.           *      //=> SELECT DISTINCT ON (id) * FROM items ORDER BY id
    176. 

  176.           *
    177. 

  177.           * @throws {patio.QueryError}  If arguments are given and DISTINCT ON is not supported.
    178. 

  178.           * @param {...String|...patio.sql.Identifier} args variable number of arguments used to create
    179. 

  179.           *                                                 the DISTINCT ON clause.
    180. 

  180.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the DISTINCT/DISTINCT ON clause added.
    181. 

  181.           */
    182. 

  182.          distinct:function (args) {
    183. 

  183. 13            args = argsToArray(arguments);
    184. 

  184. 13            if (args.length && !this.supportsDistinctOn) {
    185. 

  185. 1                throw new QueryError("DISTICT ON is not supported");
    186. 

  186.              }
    187. 

  187. 12            args = args.map(function (a) {
    188. 

  188. 6                return isString(a) ? new Identifier(a) : a;
    189. 

  189.              });
    190. 

  190. 12            return this.mergeOptions({distinct:args});
    191. 

  191.          },
    192. 

  192.  
    193. 

  193.          /**
    194. 

  194.           * Adds an EXCEPT clause using a second dataset object.
    195. 

  195.           * An EXCEPT compound dataset returns all rows in the current dataset
    196. 

  196.           * that are not in the given dataset.
    197. 

  197.           *
    198. 

  198.           * @example
    199. 

  199.           *
    200. 

  200.           * DB.from("items").except(DB.from("other_items")).sql;
    201. 

  201.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items EXCEPT SELECT * FROM other_items
    202. 

  202.           *
    203. 

  203.           * DB.from("items").except(DB.from("other_items"),
    204. 

  204.           *                        {all : true, fromSelf : false}).sql;
    205. 

  205.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items EXCEPT ALL SELECT * FROM other_items
    206. 

  206.           *
    207. 

  207.           * DB.from("items").except(DB.from("other_items"),
    208. 

  208.           *                        {alias : "i"}).sql;
    209. 

  209.           *      //=>SELECT * FROM (SELECT * FROM items EXCEPT SELECT * FROM other_items) AS i
    210. 

  210.           *
    211. 

  211.           * @throws {patio.QueryError} if the operation is not supported.
    212. 

  212.           * @param {patio.Dataset} dataset the dataset to use to create the EXCEPT clause.
    213. 

  213.           * @param {Object} [opts] options to use when creating the EXCEPT clause
    214. 

  214.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifier} [opt.alias] Use the given value as the {@link patio.Dataset#fromSelf} alias.
    215. 

  215.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.all] Set to true to use EXCEPT ALL instead of EXCEPT, so duplicate rows can occur
    216. 

  216.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.fromSelf] Set to false to not wrap the returned dataset in a {@link patio.Dataset#fromSelf}, use with care.
    217. 

  217.           *
    218. 

  218.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the EXCEPT clause added.
    219. 

  219.           */
    220. 

  220.          except:function (dataset, opts) {
    221. 

  221. 18            opts = isUndefined(opts) ? {} : opts;
    222. 

  222. 18            if (!isHash(opts)) {
    223. 

  223. 5                opts = {all:true};
    224. 

  224.              }
    225. 

  225. 18            if (!this.supportsIntersectExcept) {
    226. 

  226. 2                throw new QueryError("EXCEPT not supoorted");
    227. 

  227. 16            } else if (opts.hasOwnProperty("all") && !this.supportsIntersectExceptAll) {
    228. 

  228. 1                throw new QueryError("EXCEPT ALL not supported");
    229. 

  229.              }
    230. 

  230. 15            return this.compoundClone("except", dataset, opts);
    231. 

  231.          },
    232. 

  232.  
    233. 

  233.          /**
    234. 

  234.           * Performs the inverse of {@link patio.Dataset#filter}.  Note that if you have multiple filter
    235. 

  235.           * conditions, this is not the same as a negation of all conditions. For argument types see
    236. 

  236.           * {@link patio.Dataset#filter}
    237. 

  237.           *
    238. 

  238.           * @example
    239. 

  239.           *
    240. 

  240.           * DB.from("items").exclude({category : "software").sql;
    241. 

  241.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE (category != 'software')
    242. 

  242.           *
    243. 

  243.           * DB.from("items").exclude({category : 'software', id : 3}).sql;
    244. 

  244.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE ((category != 'software') OR (id != 3))
    245. 

  245.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the excluded conditions applied to the HAVING/WHERE clause.
    246. 

  246.           */
    247. 

  247.          exclude:function () {
    248. 

  248. 77            var cond = argsToArray(arguments), tOpts = this.__opts;
    249. 

  249. 77            var clause = (tOpts["having"] ? "having" : "where"), clauseObj = tOpts[clause];
    250. 

  250. 77            cond = cond.length > 1 ? cond : cond[0];
    251. 

  251. 77            cond = this._filterExpr.call(this, cond);
    252. 

  252. 77            cond = BooleanExpression.invert(cond);
    253. 

  253. 77            if (clauseObj) {
    254. 

  254. 66                cond = new BooleanExpression("AND", clauseObj, cond)
    255. 

  255.              }
    256. 

  256. 77            var opts = {};
    257. 

  257. 77            opts[clause] = cond;
    258. 

  258. 77            return this.mergeOptions(opts);
    259. 

  259.          },
    260. 

  260.  
    261. 

  261.          /**
    262. 

  262.           * Returns a copy of the dataset with the given conditions applied to it.
    263. 

  263.           * If the query already has a HAVING clause, then the conditions are applied to the
    264. 

  264.           * HAVING clause otherwise they are applied to the WHERE clause.
    265. 

  265.           *
    266. 

  266.           * @example
    267. 

  267.           *
    268. 

  268.           * DB.from("items").filter({id : 3}).sql;
    269. 

  269.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE (id = 3)
    270. 

  270.           *
    271. 

  271.           * DB.from("items").filter('price < ?', 100)
    272. 

  272.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE price < 100
    273. 

  273.           *
    274. 

  274.           * DB.from("items").filter({id, [1,2,3]}).filter({id : {between : [0, 10]}}).sql;
    275. 

  275.           *      //=> SELECT
    276. 

  276.           *               *
    277. 

  277.           *           FROM
    278. 

  278.           *               items
    279. 

  279.           *           WHERE
    280. 

  280.           *               ((id IN (1, 2, 3)) AND ((id >= 0) AND (id <= 10)))
    281. 

  281.           *
    282. 

  282.           * DB.from("items").filter('price < 100');
    283. 

  283.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE price < 100
    284. 

  284.           *
    285. 

  285.           * DB.from("items").filter("active").sql;
    286. 

  286.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE active
    287. 

  287.           *
    288. 

  288.           * DB.from("items").filter(function(){
    289. 

  289.           *      return this.price.lt(100);
    290. 

  290.           * });
    291. 

  291.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE (price < 100)
    292. 

  292.           *
    293. 

  293.           * //Multiple filter calls can be chained for scoping:
    294. 

  294.           * DB.from("items").filter(:category => 'software').filter{price < 100}
    295. 

  295.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE ((category = 'software') AND (price < 100))
    296. 

  296.           *
    297. 

  297.           *
    298. 

  298.           * @param {Object|Array|String|patio.sql.Identifier|patio.sql.BooleanExpression} args filters to apply to the
    299. 

  299.           *  WHERE/HAVING clause. Description of each:
    300. 

  300.           *  <ul>
    301. 

  301.           *      <li>Hash - list of equality/inclusion expressions</li>
    302. 

  302.           *      <li>Array - depends:
    303. 

  303.           *          <ul>
    304. 

  304.           *              <li>If first member is a string, assumes the rest of the arguments
    305. 

  305.           *                  are parameters and interpolates them into the string.</li>
    306. 

  306.           *              <li>If all members are arrays of length two, treats the same way
    307. 

  307.           *                  as a hash, except it allows for duplicate keys to be
    308. 

  308.           *                  specified.</li>
    309. 

  309.           *              <li>Otherwise, treats each argument as a separate condition.</li>
    310. 

  310.           *           </ul>
    311. 

  311.           *       </li>
    312. 

  312.           *      <li>String - taken literally</li>
    313. 

  313.           *      <li>{@link patio.sql.Identifier} - taken as a boolean column argument (e.g. WHERE active)</li>
    314. 

  314.           *      <li>{@link patio.sql.BooleanExpression} - an existing condition expression,
    315. 

  315.           *          probably created using the patio.sql methods.
    316. 

  316.           *       </li>
    317. 

  317.           *
    318. 

  318.           * @param {Function} [cb] filter also takes a cb, which should return one of the above argument
    319. 

  319.           * types, and is treated the same way.  This block is called with an {@link patio.sql} object which can be used to dynaically create expression.  For more details
    320. 

  320.           * on the sql object see {@link patio.sql}
    321. 

  321.           *
    322. 

  322.           * <p>
    323. 

  323.           *     <b>NOTE:</b>If both a cb and regular arguments are provided, they get ANDed together.
    324. 

  324.           * </p>
    325. 

  325.           *
    326. 

  326.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the filter arumgents applied to the WHERE/HAVING clause.
    327. 

  327.           **/
    328. 

  328.          filter:function (args, cb) {
    329. 

  329. 3846            args = [this.__opts["having"] ? "having" : "where"].concat(argsToArray(arguments));
    330. 

  330. 3846            return this._filter.apply(this, args);
    331. 

  331.          },
    332. 

  332.  
    333. 

  333.          /**
    334. 

  334.           * @see patio.Dataset#filter
    335. 

  335.           */
    336. 

  336.          find:function () {
    337. 

  337. 30            var args = [this.__opts["having"] ? "having" : "where"].concat(argsToArray(arguments));
    338. 

  338. 30            return this._filter.apply(this, args);
    339. 

  339.          },
    340. 

  340.  
    341. 

  341.          /**
    342. 

  342.           * @example
    343. 

  343.           * DB.from("table").forUpdate()
    344. 

  344.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM table FOR UPDATE
    345. 

  345.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with a "update" lock style.
    346. 

  346.           */
    347. 

  347.          forUpdate:function () {
    348. 

  348. 1            return this.lockStyle("update");
    349. 

  349.          },
    350. 

  350.  
    351. 

  351.          /**
    352. 

  352.           * Returns a copy of the dataset with the source changed. If no
    353. 

  353.           * source is given, removes all tables.  If multiple sources
    354. 

  354.           * are given, it is the same as using a CROSS JOIN (cartesian product) between all tables.
    355. 

  355.           *
    356. 

  356.           * @example
    357. 

  357.           * var dataset = DB.from("items");
    358. 

  358.           *
    359. 

  359.           * dataset.from().sql;
    360. 

  360.           *      //=> SELECT *
    361. 

  361.           *
    362. 

  362.           * dataset.from("blah").sql
    363. 

  363.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM blah
    364. 

  364.           *
    365. 

  365.           * dataset.from("blah", "foo")
    366. 

  366.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM blah, foo
    367. 

  367.           *
    368. 

  368.           * dataset.from({a:"b"}).sql;
    369. 

  369.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM a AS b
    370. 

  370.           *
    371. 

  371.           * dataset.from(dataset.from("a").group("b").as("c")).sql;
    372. 

  372.           *          //=> "SELECT * FROM (SELECT * FROM a GROUP BY b) AS c"
    373. 

  373.           *
    374. 

  374.           * @param {...String|...patio.sql.Identifier|...patio.Dataset|...Object} [source] tables to select from
    375. 

  375.           *
    376. 

  376.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the FROM clause overridden.
    377. 

  377.           */
    378. 

  378.          from:function (source) {
    379. 

  379. 891            source = argsToArray(arguments);
    380. 

  380. 891            var tableAliasNum = 0, sources = [];
    381. 

  381. 891            source.forEach(function (s) {
    382. 

  382. 1106                if (isInstanceOf(s, Dataset)) {
    383. 

  383. 86                    sources.push(new AliasedExpression(s, this._datasetAlias(++tableAliasNum)));
    384. 

  384. 1020                } else if (isHash(s)) {
    385. 

  385. 3                    for (var i in s) {
    386. 

  386. 3                        sources.push(new AliasedExpression(new Identifier(i), s[i]));
    387. 

  387.                      }
    388. 

  388. 1017                } else if (isString(s)) {
    389. 

  389. 992                    sources.push(this.stringToIdentifier(s))
    390. 

  390.                  } else {
    391. 

  391. 25                    sources.push(s);
    392. 

  392.                  }
    393. 

  393.              }, this);
    394. 

  394.  
    395. 

  395. 891            var o = {from:sources.length ? sources : null}
    396. 

  396. 891            if (tableAliasNum) {
    397. 

  397. 84                o.numDatasetSources = tableAliasNum;
    398. 

  398.              }
    399. 

  399. 891            return this.mergeOptions(o)
    400. 

  400.          },
    401. 

  401.  
    402. 

  402.          /**
    403. 

  403.           * Returns a dataset selecting from the current dataset.
    404. 

  404.           * Supplying the alias option controls the alias of the result.
    405. 

  405.           *
    406. 

  406.           * @example
    407. 

  407.           *
    408. 

  408.           * ds = DB.from("items").order("name").select("id", "name")
    409. 

  409.           *      //=> SELECT id,name FROM items ORDER BY name
    410. 

  410.           *
    411. 

  411.           * ds.fromSelf().sql;
    412. 

  412.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM (SELECT id, name FROM items ORDER BY name) AS t1
    413. 

  413.           *
    414. 

  414.           * ds.fromSelf({alias : "foo"}).sql;
    415. 

  415.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM (SELECT id, name FROM items ORDER BY name) AS foo
    416. 

  416.           *
    417. 

  417.           * @param {Object} [opts] options
    418. 

  418.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifier} [opts.alias] alias to use
    419. 

  419.           *
    420. 

  420.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the FROM clause set as the current dataset.
    421. 

  421.           */
    422. 

  422.          fromSelf:function (opts) {
    423. 

  423. 84            opts = isUndefined(opts) ? {} : opts;
    424. 

  424. 84            var fs = {};
    425. 

  425. 84            var nonSqlOptions = this._static.NON_SQL_OPTIONS;
    426. 

  426. 84            Object.keys(this.__opts).forEach(function (k) {
    427. 

  427. 302                if (nonSqlOptions.indexOf(k) == -1) {
    428. 

  428. 302                    fs[k] = null;
    429. 

  429.                  }
    430. 

  430.              });
    431. 

  431. 84            return this.mergeOptions(fs).from(opts["alias"] ? this.as(opts["alias"]) : this);
    432. 

  432.          },
    433. 

  433.  
    434. 

  434.          /**
    435. 

  435.           * Match any of the columns to any of the patterns. The terms can be
    436. 

  436.           * strings (which use LIKE) or regular expressions (which are only
    437. 

  437.           * supported on MySQL and PostgreSQL).  Note that the total number of
    438. 

  438.           * pattern matches will be columns[].length * terms[].length,
    439. 

  439.           * which could cause performance issues.
    440. 

  440.           *
    441. 

  441.           * @example
    442. 

  442.           *
    443. 

  443.           * DB.from("items").grep("a", "%test%").sql;
    444. 

  444.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE (a LIKE '%test%');
    445. 

  445.           *
    446. 

  446.           * DB.from("items").grep(["a", "b"], ["%test%" "foo"]).sql;
    447. 

  447.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE ((a LIKE '%test%') OR (a LIKE 'foo') OR (b LIKE '%test%') OR (b LIKE 'foo'))
    448. 

  448.           *
    449. 

  449.           * DB.from("items").grep(['a', 'b'], ["%foo%", "%bar%"], {allPatterns : true}).sql;
    450. 

  450.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM a WHERE (((a LIKE '%foo%') OR (b LIKE '%foo%')) AND ((a LIKE '%bar%') OR (b LIKE '%bar%')))
    451. 

  451.           *
    452. 

  452.           * DB.from("items").grep(["a", "b"], ['%foo%", "%bar%", {allColumns : true})sql;
    453. 

  453.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM a WHERE (((a LIKE '%foo%') OR (a LIKE '%bar%')) AND ((b LIKE '%foo%') OR (b LIKE '%bar%')))
    454. 

  454.           *
    455. 

  455.           * DB.from("items").grep(["a", "b"], ["%foo%", "%bar%"], {allPatterns : true, allColumns : true}).sql;
    456. 

  456.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM a WHERE ((a LIKE '%foo%') AND (b LIKE '%foo%') AND (a LIKE '%bar%') AND (b LIKE '%bar%'))
    457. 

  457.           *
    458. 

  458.           * @param {String[]|patio.sql.Identifier[]} columns columns to search
    459. 

  459.           * @param {String|RegExp} patterns patters to search with
    460. 

  460.           * @param {Object} [opts] options to use when searching. NOTE If both allColumns and allPatterns are true, all columns must match all patterns
    461. 

  461.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.allColumns] All columns must be matched to any of the given patterns.
    462. 

  462.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.allPatterns] All patterns must match at least one of the columns.
    463. 

  463.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.caseInsensitive] Use a case insensitive pattern match (the default is
    464. 

  464.           *                      case sensitive if the database supports it).
    465. 

  465.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a dataset with the LIKE clauses added
    466. 

  466.           */
    467. 

  467.  
    468. 

  468.          grep:function (columns, patterns, opts) {
    469. 

  469. 15            opts = isUndefined(opts) ? {} : opts;
    470. 

  470. 15            var conds;
    471. 

  471. 15            if (opts.hasOwnProperty("allPatterns")) {
    472. 

  472. 4                conds = array.toArray(patterns).map(function (pat) {
    473. 

  473. 8                    return BooleanExpression.fromArgs(
    474. 

  474.                          [(opts.allColumns ? "AND" : "OR")]
    475. 

  475.                              .concat(array.toArray(columns)
    476. 

  476.                              .map(function (c) {
    477. 

  477. 16                                return StringExpression.like(c, pat, opts);
    478. 

  478.                              })));
    479. 

  479.                  });
    480. 

  480. 4                return this.filter(BooleanExpression.fromArgs([opts.allPatterns ? "AND" : "OR"].concat(conds)));
    481. 

  481.              } else {
    482. 

  482. 11                conds = array.toArray(columns)
    483. 

  483.                      .map(function (c) {
    484. 

  484. 16                        return BooleanExpression.fromArgs(["OR"].concat(array.toArray(patterns).map(function (pat) {
    485. 

  485. 26                            return StringExpression.like(c, pat, opts);
    486. 

  486.                          })));
    487. 

  487.                      });
    488. 

  488. 11                return this.filter(BooleanExpression.fromArgs([opts.allColumns ? "AND" : "OR"].concat(conds)));
    489. 

  489.              }
    490. 

  490.          },
    491. 

  491.  
    492. 

  492.          /**
    493. 

  493.           * @see patio.Dataset#grep
    494. 

  494.           */
    495. 

  495.          like:function () {
    496. 

  496. 1            return this.grep.apply(this, arguments);
    497. 

  497.          },
    498. 

  498.  
    499. 

  499.  
    500. 

  500.          /**
    501. 

  501.           * Returns a copy of the dataset with the results grouped by the value of
    502. 

  502.           * the given columns.
    503. 

  503.           * @example
    504. 

  504.           *   DB.from("items").group("id")
    505. 

  505.           *          //=>SELECT * FROM items GROUP BY id
    506. 

  506.           *   DB.from("items").group("id", "name")
    507. 

  507.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM items GROUP BY id, name
    508. 

  508.           * @param {String...|patio.sql.Identifier...} columns columns to group by.
    509. 

  509.           *
    510. 

  510.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the GROUP BY clause added.
    511. 

  511.           **/
    512. 

  512.          group:function (columns) {
    513. 

  513. 32            columns = argsToArray(arguments);
    514. 

  514. 32            var stringToIdentifier = this.stringToIdentifier.bind(this)
    515. 

  515. 32            return this.mergeOptions({group:(array.compact(columns).length == 0 ? null : columns.map(function (c) {
    516. 

  516. 32                return isString(c) ? stringToIdentifier(c) : c;
    517. 

  517.              }))});
    518. 

  518.          },
    519. 

  519.  
    520. 

  520.          /**
    521. 

  521.           * @see patio.Dataset#group
    522. 

  522.           */
    523. 

  523.          groupBy:function () {
    524. 

  524. 10            return this.group.apply(this, arguments);
    525. 

  525.          },
    526. 

  526.  
    527. 

  527.  
    528. 

  528.          /**
    529. 

  529.           * Returns a dataset grouped by the given column with count by group.
    530. 

  530.           * Column aliases may be supplied, and will be included in the select clause.
    531. 

  531.           *
    532. 

  532.           * @example
    533. 

  533.           *
    534. 

  534.           * DB.from("items").groupAndCount("name").all()
    535. 

  535.           *      //=> SELECT name, count(*) AS count FROM items GROUP BY name
    536. 

  536.           *      //=> [{name : 'a', count : 1}, ...]
    537. 

  537.           *
    538. 

  538.           * DB.from("items").groupAndCount("first_name", "last_name").all()
    539. 

  539.           *      //SELECT first_name, last_name, count(*) AS count FROM items GROUP BY first_name, last_name
    540. 

  540.           *      //=> [{first_name : 'a', last_name : 'b', count : 1}, ...]
    541. 

  541.           *
    542. 

  542.           * DB.from("items").groupAndCount("first_name___name").all()
    543. 

  543.           *      //=> SELECT first_name AS name, count(*) AS count FROM items GROUP BY first_name
    544. 

  544.           *      //=> [{name : 'a', count:1}, ...]
    545. 

  545.           * @param {String...|patio.sql.Identifier...} columns columns to croup and count on.
    546. 

  546.           *
    547. 

  547.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the GROUP clause and count added.
    548. 

  548.           */
    549. 

  549.          groupAndCount:function (columns) {
    550. 

  550. 8            columns = argsToArray(arguments);
    551. 

  551. 8            var group = this.group.apply(this, columns.map(function (c) {
    552. 

  552. 9                return this._unaliasedIdentifier(c);
    553. 

  553.              }, this));
    554. 

  554. 8            return group.select.apply(group, columns.concat([this._static.COUNT_OF_ALL_AS_COUNT]));
    555. 

  555.  
    556. 

  556.          },
    557. 

  557.  
    558. 

  558.          /**
    559. 

  559.           * Returns a copy of the dataset with the HAVING conditions changed. See {@link patio.Dataset#filter} for argument types.
    560. 

  560.           *
    561. 

  561.           * @example
    562. 

  562.           * DB.from("items").group("sum").having({sum : 10}).sql;
    563. 

  563.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items GROUP BY sum HAVING (sum = 10)
    564. 

  564.           *
    565. 

  565.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with HAVING clause changed or added.
    566. 

  566.           **/
    567. 

  567.          having:function () {
    568. 

  568. 12            var cond = argsToArray(arguments).map(function (s) {
    569. 

  569. 12                return isString(s) && s !== '' ? this.stringToIdentifier(s) : s
    570. 

  570.              }, this);
    571. 

  571. 12            return this._filter.apply(this, ["having"].concat(cond));
    572. 

  572.          },
    573. 

  573.  
    574. 

  574.          /**
    575. 

  575.           * Adds an INTERSECT clause using a second dataset object.
    576. 

  576.           * An INTERSECT compound dataset returns all rows in both the current dataset
    577. 

  577.           * and the given dataset.
    578. 

  578.           *
    579. 

  579.           * @example
    580. 

  580.           *
    581. 

  581.           * DB.from("items").intersect(DB.from("other_items")).sql;
    582. 

  582.           *   //=> SELECT * FROM (SELECT * FROM items INTERSECT SELECT * FROM other_items) AS t1
    583. 

  583.           *
    584. 

  584.           * DB.from("items").intersect(DB.from("other_items"), {all : true, fromSelf : false}).sql;
    585. 

  585.           *   //=> SELECT * FROM items INTERSECT ALL SELECT * FROM other_items
    586. 

  586.           *
    587. 

  587.           * DB.from("items").intersect(DB.from("other_items"), {alias : "i"}).sql;
    588. 

  588.           *   //=> SELECT * FROM (SELECT * FROM items INTERSECT SELECT * FROM other_items) AS i
    589. 

  589.           *
    590. 

  590.           * @throws {patio.QueryError} if the operation is not supported.
    591. 

  591.           * @param  {patio.Dataset} dataset the dataset to intersect
    592. 

  592.           * @param  {Object} [opts] options
    593. 

  593.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifier} [opts.alias] Use the given value as the {@link patio.Dataset#fromSelf} alias
    594. 

  594.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.all] Set to true to use INTERSECT ALL instead of INTERSECT, so duplicate rows can occur
    595. 

  595.           * @param {Boolean} [opts.fromSelf] Set to false to not wrap the returned dataset in a {@link patio.Dataset#fromSelf}.
    596. 

  596.           *
    597. 

  597.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the INTERSECT clause.
    598. 

  598.           **/
    599. 

  599.          intersect:function (dataset, opts) {
    600. 

  600. 18            opts = isUndefined(opts) ? {} : opts;
    601. 

  601. 18            if (!isHash(opts)) {
    602. 

  602. 5                opts = {all:opts};
    603. 

  603.              }
    604. 

  604. 18            if (!this.supportsIntersectExcept) {
    605. 

  605. 2                throw new QueryError("INTERSECT not supported");
    606. 

  606. 16            } else if (opts.all && !this.supportsIntersectExceptAll) {
    607. 

  607. 1                throw new QueryError("INTERSECT ALL not supported");
    608. 

  608.              }
    609. 

  609. 15            return this.compoundClone("intersect", dataset, opts);
    610. 

  610.          },
    611. 

  611.  
    612. 

  612.          /**
    613. 

  613.           * Inverts the current filter.
    614. 

  614.           *
    615. 

  615.           * @example
    616. 

  616.           * DB.from("items").filter({category : 'software'}).invert()
    617. 

  617.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE (category != 'software')
    618. 

  618.           *
    619. 

  619.           * @example
    620. 

  620.           * DB.from("items").filter({category : 'software', id : 3}).invert()
    621. 

  621.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE ((category != 'software') OR (id != 3))
    622. 

  622.           *
    623. 

  623.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the filter inverted.
    624. 

  624.           **/
    625. 

  625.          invert:function () {
    626. 

  626. 3            var having = this.__opts.having, where = this.__opts.where;
    627. 

  627. 3            if (!(having || where)) {
    628. 

  628. 1                throw new QueryError("No current filter");
    629. 

  629.              }
    630. 

  630. 2            var o = {}
    631. 

  631. 2            if (having) {
    632. 

  632. 1                o.having = BooleanExpression.invert(having);
    633. 

  633.              }
    634. 

  634. 2            if (where) {
    635. 

  635. 2                o.where = BooleanExpression.invert(where);
    636. 

  636.              }
    637. 

  637. 2            return this.mergeOptions(o);
    638. 

  638.          },
    639. 

  639.  
    640. 

  640.          /**
    641. 

  641.           * Returns a cloned dataset with an inner join applied.
    642. 

  642.           *
    643. 

  643.           * @see patio.Dataset#joinTable
    644. 

  644.           */
    645. 

  645.          join:function () {
    646. 

  646. 236            return this.innerJoin.apply(this, arguments);
    647. 

  647.          },
    648. 

  648.  
    649. 

  649.          /**
    650. 

  650.           * Returns a joined dataset.  Uses the following arguments:
    651. 

  651.           *
    652. 

  652.           * @example
    653. 

  653.           *
    654. 

  654.           * DB.from("items").joinTable("leftOuter", "categories", [["categoryId", "id"],["categoryId", [1, 2, 3]]]).sql;
    655. 

  655.           *      //=>'SELECT
    656. 

  656.           *             *
    657. 

  657.           *            FROM
    658. 

  658.           *              `items`
    659. 

  659.           *                  LEFT OUTER JOIN
    660. 

  660.           *              `categories` ON (
    661. 

  661.           *                          (`categories`.`categoryId` = `items`.`id`)
    662. 

  662.           *                              AND
    663. 

  663.           *                          (`categories`.`categoryId` IN (1,2, 3))
    664. 

  664.           *                          )
    665. 

  665.           * DB.from("items").leftOuter("categories", [["categoryId", "id"],["categoryId", [1, 2, 3]]]).sql;
    666. 

  666.           *      //=>'SELECT
    667. 

  667.           *             *
    668. 

  668.           *            FROM
    669. 

  669.           *              `items`
    670. 

  670.           *                  LEFT OUTER JOIN
    671. 

  671.           *              `categories` ON (
    672. 

  672.           *                          (`categories`.`categoryId` = `items`.`id`)
    673. 

  673.           *                              AND
    674. 

  674.           *                          (`categories`.`categoryId` IN (1,2, 3))
    675. 

  675.           *                          )
    676. 

  676.           *
    677. 

  677.           * DB.from("items").leftOuterJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    678. 

  678.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" LEFT OUTER JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    679. 

  679.           *
    680. 

  680.           * DB.from("items").rightOuterJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    681. 

  681.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" RIGHT OUTER JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    682. 

  682.           *
    683. 

  683.           * DB.from("items").fullOuterJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    684. 

  684.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" FULL OUTER JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    685. 

  685.           *
    686. 

  686.           * DB.from("items").innerJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    687. 

  687.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" INNER JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    688. 

  688.           *
    689. 

  689.           * DB.from("items").leftJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    690. 

  690.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" LEFT JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    691. 

  691.           *
    692. 

  692.           * DB.from("items").rightJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    693. 

  693.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" RIGHT JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    694. 

  694.           *
    695. 

  695.           * DB.from("items").fullJoin("categories", {categoryId:"id"}).sql
    696. 

  696.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" FULL JOIN "categories" ON ("categories"."categoryId" = "items"."id")
    697. 

  697.           *
    698. 

  698.           * DB.from("items").naturalJoin("categories").sql
    699. 

  699.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" NATURAL JOIN "categories"
    700. 

  700.           *
    701. 

  701.           * DB.from("items").naturalLeftJoin("categories").sql
    702. 

  702.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" NATURAL LEFT JOIN "categories"
    703. 

  703.           *
    704. 

  704.           * DB.from("items").naturalRightJoin("categories").sql
    705. 

  705.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" NATURAL RIGHT JOIN "categories"
    706. 

  706.           *
    707. 

  707.           * DB.from("items").naturalFullJoin("categories").sql
    708. 

  708.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" NATURAL FULL JOIN "categories"'
    709. 

  709.           *
    710. 

  710.           * DB.from("items").crossJoin("categories").sql
    711. 

  711.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM "items" CROSS JOIN "categories"
    712. 

  712.           *
    713. 

  713.           * @param {String} type the type of join to do.
    714. 

  714.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifier|patio.Dataset|Object} table depends on the type.
    715. 

  715.           *  <ul>
    716. 

  716.           *      <li>{@link patio.Dataset} - a subselect is performed with an alias</li>
    717. 

  717.           *      <li>Object - an object that has a tableName property.</li>
    718. 

  718.           *      <li>String|{@link patio.sql.Identifier}  - the name of the table</li>
    719. 

  719.           *  </ul>
    720. 

  720.           * @param [expr] - depends on type
    721. 

  721.           * <ul>
    722. 

  722.           *     <li>Object|Array of two element arrays - Assumes key (1st arg) is column of joined table (unless already
    723. 

  723.           *     qualified), and value (2nd arg) is column of the last joined or primary table (or the
    724. 

  724.           *     implicitQualifier option</li>.
    725. 

  725.           *     <li>Array - If all members of the array are string or {@link patio.sql.Identifier}, considers
    726. 

  726.           *     them as columns and uses a JOIN with a USING clause.  Most databases will remove duplicate columns from
    727. 

  727.           *     the result set if this is used.</li>
    728. 

  728.           *     <li>null|undefined(not passed in) - If a cb is not given, doesn't use ON or USING, so the JOIN should be a NATURAL
    729. 

  729.           *     or CROSS join. If a block is given, uses an ON clause based on the block, see below.</li>
    730. 

  730.           *     <li>Everything else - pretty much the same as a using the argument in a call to {@link patio.Dataset#filter},
    731. 

  731.           *     so strings are considered literal, {@link patio.sql.Identifiers} specify boolean columns, and patio.sql
    732. 

  732.           *      expressions can be used. Uses a JOIN with an ON clause.</li>
    733. 

  733.           * </ul>
    734. 

  734.           * @param {Object} options an object of options.
    735. 

  735.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifier} [options.tableAlias=undefined] the name of the table's alias when joining, necessary for joining
    736. 

  736.           *     to the same table more than once.  No alias is used by default.
    737. 

  737.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifier} [options.implicitQualifier=undefined] The name to use for qualifying implicit conditions.  By default,
    738. 

  738.           *     the last joined or primary table is used.
    739. 

  739.           * @param {Function} [cb]  cb - The cb argument should only be given if a JOIN with an ON clause is used,
    740. 

  740.           *   in which case it is called with
    741. 

  741.           *   <ul>
    742. 

  742.           *       <li>table alias/name for the table currently being joined</li>
    743. 

  743.           *       <li> the table alias/name for the last joined (or first table)
    744. 

  744.           *       <li>array of previous</li>
    745. 

  745.           *   </ul>
    746. 

  746.           *   the cb should return an expression to be used in the ON clause.
    747. 

  747.           *
    748. 

  748.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset joined using the arguments.
    749. 

  749.           */
    750. 

  750.  
    751. 

  751.          joinTable:function (type, table, expr, options, cb) {
    752. 

  752. 797            var args = argsToArray(arguments);
    753. 

  753. 797            if (isFunction(args[args.length - 1])) {
    754. 

  754. 12                cb = args[args.length - 1];
    755. 

  755. 12                args.pop();
    756. 

  756.              } else {
    757. 

  757. 785                cb = null;
    758. 

  758.              }
    759. 

  759. 797            type = args.shift(), table = args.shift(), expr = args.shift(), options = args.shift();
    760. 

  760. 797            expr = isUndefined(expr) ? null : expr, options = isUndefined(options) ? {} : options;
    761. 

  761.  
    762. 

  762. 797            var h;
    763. 

  763. 797            var usingJoin = isArray(expr) && expr.length && expr.every(function (x) {
    764. 

  764. 346                return isString(x) || isInstanceOf(x, Identifier)
    765. 

  765.              });
    766. 

  766. 797            if (usingJoin && !this.supportsJoinUsing) {
    767. 

  767. 1                h = {};
    768. 

  768. 1                expr.forEach(function (s) {
    769. 

  769. 1                    h[s] = s;
    770. 

  770.                  });
    771. 

  771. 1                return this.joinTable(type, table, h, options);
    772. 

  772.              }
    773. 

  773. 796            var tableAlias, lastAlias;
    774. 

  774. 796            if (isHash(options)) {
    775. 

  775. 786                tableAlias = options.tableAlias;
    776. 

  776. 786                lastAlias = options.implicitQualifier;
    777. 

  777. 10            } else if (isString(options) || isInstanceOf(options, Identifier)) {
    778. 

  778. 9                tableAlias = options;
    779. 

  779. 9                lastAlias = null;
    780. 

  780.              } else {
    781. 

  781. 1                throw new QueryError("Invalid options format for joinTable %j4", [options]);
    782. 

  782.              }
    783. 

  783. 795            var tableAliasNum, tableName;
    784. 

  784. 795            if (isInstanceOf(table, Dataset)) {
    785. 

  785. 11                if (!tableAlias) {
    786. 

  786. 6                    tableAliasNum = (this.__opts.numDatasetSources || 0) + 1;
    787. 

  787. 6                    tableAlias = this._datasetAlias(tableAliasNum);
    788. 

  788.                  }
    789. 

  789. 11                tableName = tableAlias;
    790. 

  790.              } else {
    791. 

  791. 784                if (!isUndefined(table.tableName)) {
    792. 

  792. 1                    table = table.tableName;
    793. 

  793.                  }
    794. 

  794. 784                if (isArray(table)) {
    795. 

  795. 2                    table = table.map(this.stringToIdentifier, this);
    796. 

  796.                  } else {
    797. 

  797. 782                    table = isString(table) ? this.stringToIdentifier(table) : table;
    798. 

  798. 782                    var parts = this._splitAlias(table), implicitTableAlias = parts[1];
    799. 

  799. 782                    table = parts[0]
    800. 

  800. 782                    tableAlias = tableAlias || implicitTableAlias;
    801. 

  801. 782                    tableName = tableAlias || table;
    802. 

  802.                  }
    803. 

  803.              }
    804. 

  804. 795            var join;
    805. 

  805. 795            if (!expr && !cb) {
    806. 

  806. 22                join = new JoinClause(type, table, tableAlias);
    807. 

  807. 773            } else if (usingJoin) {
    808. 

  808. 9                if (cb) {
    809. 

  809. 1                    throw new QueryError("cant use a cb if an array is given");
    810. 

  810.                  }
    811. 

  811. 8                join = new JoinUsingClause(expr, type, table, tableAlias);
    812. 

  812.              } else {
    813. 

  813. 764                lastAlias = lastAlias || this.__opts["lastJoinedTable"] || this.firstSourceAlias;
    814. 

  814. 763                if (Expression.isConditionSpecifier(expr)) {
    815. 

  815. 751                    var newExpr = [];
    816. 

  816. 751                    for (var i in expr) {
    817. 

  817. 1211                        var val = expr[i];
    818. 

  818. 1211                        if (isArray(val) && val.length == 2) {
    819. 

  819. 664                            i = val[0], val = val[1];
    820. 

  820.                          }
    821. 

  821. 1211                        var k = this.qualifiedColumnName(i, tableName), v;
    822. 

  822. 1211                        if (isInstanceOf(val, Identifier)) {
    823. 

  823. 544                            v = val.qualify(lastAlias);
    824. 

  824.                          } else {
    825. 

  825. 667                            v = val;
    826. 

  826.                          }
    827. 

  827. 1211                        newExpr.push([k, v]);
    828. 

  828.                      }
    829. 

  829. 751                    expr = newExpr;
    830. 

  830.                  }
    831. 

  831. 763                if (isFunction(cb)) {
    832. 

  832. 11                    var expr2 = cb.apply(sql, [tableName, lastAlias, this.__opts.join || []]);
    833. 

  833. 11                    expr = expr ? new BooleanExpression("AND", expr, expr2) : expr2;
    834. 

  834.                  }
    835. 

  835. 763                join = new JoinOnClause(expr, type, table, tableAlias);
    836. 

  836.              }
    837. 

  837. 793            var opts = {join:(this.__opts.join || []).concat([join]), lastJoinedTable:tableName};
    838. 

  838. 793            if (tableAliasNum) {
    839. 

  839. 6                opts.numDatasetSources = tableAliasNum;
    840. 

  840.              }
    841. 

  841. 793            return this.mergeOptions(opts);
    842. 

  842.  
    843. 

  843.          },
    844. 

  844.  
    845. 

  845.          /**
    846. 

  846.           * If given an integer, the dataset will contain only the first l results.
    847. 

  847.           If a second argument is given, it is used as an offset. To use
    848. 

  848.           * an offset without a limit, pass null as the first argument.
    849. 

  849.           *
    850. 

  850.           * @example
    851. 

  851.           *
    852. 

  852.           * DB.from("items").limit(10)
    853. 

  853.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items LIMIT 10
    854. 

  854.           * DB.from("items").limit(10, 20)
    855. 

  855.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20
    856. 

  856.           * DB.from("items").limit([3, 7]).sql
    857. 

  857.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items LIMIT 5 OFFSET 3');
    858. 

  858.           * DB.from("items").limit(null, 20)
    859. 

  859.           *      //=> SELECT * FROM items OFFSET 20
    860. 

  860.           *
    861. 

  861.           * DB.from("items").limit('6', sql['a() - 1']).sql
    862. 

  862.           *      => 'SELECT * FROM items LIMIT 6 OFFSET a() - 1');
    863. 

  863.           *
    864. 

  864.           * @param {Number|String|Number[]} limit the limit to apply
    865. 

  865.           * @param {Number|String|patio.sql.LiteralString} offset the offset to apply
    866. 

  866.           *
    867. 

  867.           * @return {patio.Dataset}  a cloned dataset witht the LIMIT and OFFSET applied.
    868. 

  868.           **/
    869. 

  869.          limit:function (limit, offset) {
    870. 

  870. 46            if (this.__opts.sql) {
    871. 

  871. 7                return this.fromSelf().limit(limit, offset);
    872. 

  872.              }
    873. 

  873. 39            if (isArray(limit) && limit.length == 2) {
    874. 

  874. 1                offset = limit[0];
    875. 

  875. 1                limit = limit[1] - limit[0] + 1;
    876. 

  876.              }
    877. 

  877. 39            if (isString(limit) || isInstanceOf(limit, LiteralString)) {
    878. 

  878. 2                limit = parseInt("" + limit, 10);
    879. 

  879.              }
    880. 

  880. 39            if (isNumber(limit) && limit < 1) {
    881. 

  881. 2                throw new QueryError("Limit must be >= 1");
    882. 

  882.              }
    883. 

  883. 37            var opts = {limit:limit};
    884. 

  884. 37            if (offset) {
    885. 

  885. 9                if (isString(offset) || isInstanceOf(offset, LiteralString)) {
    886. 

  886. 1                    offset = parseInt("" + offset, 10);
    887. 

  887. 1                    isNaN(offset) && (offset = 0);
    888. 

  888.                  }
    889. 

  889. 9                if (isNumber(offset) && offset < 0) {
    890. 

  890. 1                    throw new QueryError("Offset must be >= 0");
    891. 

  891.                  }
    892. 

  892. 8                opts.offset = offset;
    893. 

  893.              }
    894. 

  894. 36            return this.mergeOptions(opts);
    895. 

  895.          },
    896. 

  896.  
    897. 

  897.          /**
    898. 

  898.           *
    899. 

  899.           * Returns a cloned dataset with a not equal expression added to the WHERE
    900. 

  900.           * clause.
    901. 

  901.           *
    902. 

  902.           * @example
    903. 

  903.           *  DB.from("test").neq({x : 1});
    904. 

  904.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE (x != 1)
    905. 

  905.           *  DB.from("test").neq({x : 1, y : 10});
    906. 

  906.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE ((x != 1) AND (y != 10))
    907. 

  907.           *
    908. 

  908.           * @param {Object} obj object used to create the not equal expression
    909. 

  909.           *
    910. 

  910.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the not equal expression added to the WHERE clause.
    911. 

  911.           */
    912. 

  912.          neq:function (obj) {
    913. 

  913. 2            return this.filter(this.__createBoolExpression("neq", obj));
    914. 

  914.          },
    915. 

  915.  
    916. 

  916.          /**
    917. 

  917.           *
    918. 

  918.           * Returns a cloned dataset with an equal expression added to the WHERE
    919. 

  919.           * clause.
    920. 

  920.           *
    921. 

  921.           * @example
    922. 

  922.           *  DB.from("test").eq({x : 1});
    923. 

  923.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE (x = 1)
    924. 

  924.           *  DB.from("test").eq({x : 1, y : 10});
    925. 

  925.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE ((x = 1) AND (y = 10))
    926. 

  926.           *
    927. 

  927.           * @param {Object} obj object used to create the equal expression
    928. 

  928.           *
    929. 

  929.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the equal expression added to the WHERE clause.
    930. 

  930.           */
    931. 

  931.          eq:function (obj) {
    932. 

  932. 2            return this.filter(this.__createBoolExpression("eq", obj));
    933. 

  933.          },
    934. 

  934.  
    935. 

  935.          /**
    936. 

  936.           *
    937. 

  937.           * Returns a cloned dataset with a greater than expression added to the WHERE
    938. 

  938.           * clause.
    939. 

  939.           *
    940. 

  940.           * @example
    941. 

  941.           *  DB.from("test").gt({x : 1});
    942. 

  942.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE (x > 1)
    943. 

  943.           *  DB.from("test").gt({x : 1, y : 10});
    944. 

  944.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE ((x > 1) AND (y > 10))
    945. 

  945.           *

    947.

    948.

    949. 

  949.           */
    950. 

  950.          gt:function (obj) {
    951. 

  951. 2            return this.filter(this.__createBoolExpression("gt", obj));
    952. 

  952.          },
    953. 

  953.  
    954. 

  954.          /**
    955. 

  955.           *
    956.

    957. 

  957.           * clause.
    958. 

  958.           *
    959. 

  959.           * @example
    960. 

  960.           *  DB.from("test").lt({x : 1});
    961. 

  961.           *          //=> SELECT * FROM test WHERE (x < 1)
    962. 

  962.           *  DB.from("test").lt({x : 1, y : 10});

    971. 

  971.          },

  972.  
    973. 

  973.          /**
    974. 

  974.           * Returnes a cloned dataset with the IS NOT expression added to the WHERE
    975. 

  975.           * clause.
    976. 

  976.           *
    977. 

  977.           * @example
    978. 

  978.           *
    979. 

  979.           * DB.from("test").isNot({boolFlag : null});
    980. 

  980.           *      => SELECT * FROM test WHERE (boolFlag IS NOT NULL);
    981. 

  981.           * DB.from("test").isNot({boolFlag : false, otherFlag : true, name : null});
    982. 

  982.           *      => SELECT * FROM test WHERE ((boolFlag IS NOT FALSE) AND (otherFlag IS NOT TRUE) AND (name IS NOT NULL));
    983. 

  983.           *
    984. 

  984.           * @param {Object} obj object used to create the IS NOT expression for.
    985. 

  985.           *
    986. 

  986.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a cloned dataset with the IS NOT expression added to the WHERE clause.
    987. 

  987.           *
    988. 

  988.           */
    989. 

  989.          isNot:function (obj) {
    990. 

  990. 4            return this.filter(this.__createBoolExpression("isNot", obj));
    991. 

  991.          },
    992. 

  992.  
    993. 

  993.          /**
    994. 

  994.           * Returnes a cloned dataset with the IS expression added to the WHERE
    995. 

  995.           * clause.
    996. 

  996.           *
    997. 

  997.           * @example
    998. 

  998.           *
    999. 

  999.           * DB.from("test").is({boolFlag : null});
    1000. 

  1000.           *      => SELECT * FROM test WHERE (boolFlag IS NULL);
    1001. 

  1001.           * DB.from("test").is({boolFlag : false, otherFlag : true, name : null});
    1002. 

  1002.           *      => SELECT * FROM test WHERE ((boolFlag IS FALSE) AND (otherFlag IS TRUE) AND (name IS NULL));
    1003. 

  1003.           *
    1004. 

  1004.           * @param {Object} obj object used to create the IS expression for.
    1005. 

  1005.           *
    1006.

    1007. 

  1007.           *
    1008. 

  1008.           */

    1010. 

  1010. 4            return this.filter(this.__createBoolExpression("is", obj));
    1011. 

  1011.          },
    1012. 

  1012.

  1013.          /**
    1014.

    1015. 

  1015.           * clause.

    1017.

    1018.

    1031. 

  1031. 2            return this.filter(this.__createBoolExpression("isNot", arr));
    1032. 

  1032.          },
    1033. 

  1033.  
    1034.

    1114.

    1115.

    1116. 

  1116.  
    1117.

    1118.

    1119.

    1122.

  1124.           *      => SELECT * FROM test WHERE (boolFlag IS FALSE);
    1125. 

  1125.           * DB.from("test").isFalse("boolFlag", "otherFlag");

    1128.
