  41. 1define(null, {
    42. 

  42.      /**@ignore*/
    43. 

  43.      instance:{
    44. 

  44.  
    45. 

  45.          /**
    46. 

  46.           * @lends patio.Dataset.prototype
    47. 

  47.           */
    48. 

  48.  
    49. 

  49.          /**
    50. 

  50.           * @ignore
    51. 

  51.           */
    52. 

  52.          constructor:function () {
    53. 

  53. 28756            !Dataset && (Dataset = require("../index").Dataset);
    54. 

  54. 28756            this._super(arguments);
    55. 

  55.          },
    56. 

  56.  
    57. 

  57.          /**
    58. 

  58.           * Adds the given graph aliases to the list of graph aliases to use,
    59. 

  59.           * unlike {@link patio.Dataset#setGraphAliases}, which replaces the list (the equivalent
    60. 

  60.           * of {@link patio.Dataset#selectMore} when graphing).  See {@link patio.Dataset#setGraphAliases}.
    61. 

  61.           *
    62. 

  62.           * @example
    63. 

  63.           *  var DB = patio.defaultDatabase;
    64. 

  64.           *  // SELECT ..., table.column AS someAlias
    65. 

  65.           *   DB.from("table").addGraphAliases({someAlias : ["table", "column"]);
    66. 

  66.           *   //returns from graphing
    67. 

  67.           *   // => {table : {column : someAlias_value, ...}, ...}
    68. 

  68.           *
    69. 

  69.           *   @param {Object} graphAliases the graph aliases to use.
    70. 

  70.           *          Where key is the alias name and the value is an array where arr[0] = 'tableName' arr[1] = "colName'.
    71. 

  71.           *
    72. 

  72.           *   @return {patio.Dataset} deep copy of the original dataset with the added graphAliases.
    73. 

  73.           */
    74. 

  74.          addGraphAliases:function (graphAliases) {
    75. 

  75. 3            var ds = this.selectMore.apply(this, this.__graphAliasColumns(graphAliases));
    76. 

  76. 3            ds.__opts.graphAliases = merge((ds.__opts.graphAliases || (ds.__opts.graph ? ds.__opts.graph.columnAliases : {}) || {}), graphAliases);
    77. 

  77. 3            return ds;
    78. 

  78.          },
    79. 

  79.  
    80. 

  80.          /**
    81. 

  81.           * Allows you to join multiple datasets/tables and have the result set
    82. 

  82.           * split into component tables.
    83. 

  83.           *
    84. 

  84.           * This differs from the usual usage of join, which returns the result set
    85. 

  85.           * as a single hash.
    86. 

  86.           *
    87. 

  87.           * <pre class="code">
    88. 

  88.           *
    89. 

  89.           * //CREATE TABLE artists (id INTEGER, name TEXT);
    90. 

  90.           * //CREATE TABLE albums (id INTEGER, name TEXT, artist_id INTEGER);
    91. 

  91.           *
    92. 

  92.           * var DB = patio.defaultDatabase, ds = db.from("artists");
    93. 

  93.           * ds.leftOuterJoin("albums", {artistId : "id"}).first
    94. 

  94.           *   //=> {id : albums.id, name : albums.name, artist_id : albums.artist_id}
    95. 

  95.           *
    96. 

  96.           * var p = comb.executeInOrder(ds, function(ds){
    97. 

  97.           *   var graphedDs = ds.graph("albums", {artist_id : "id"});
    98. 

  98.           *   return graphedDs.first();
    99. 

  99.           * });
    100. 

  100.           * p.then(function(obj){
    101. 

  101.           *    //obj == {artists : {
    102. 

  102.           *                  id : artists.id,
    103. 

  103.           *                  name : artists.name
    104. 

  104.           *                  },
    105. 

  105.           *             albums : {
    106. 

  106.           *                  id : albums.id,
    107. 

  107.           *                  name : albums.name,
    108. 

  108.           *                  artist_id=>albums.artist_id
    109. 

  109.           *                  }
    110. 

  110.           *             }
    111. 

  111.           * });
    112. 

  112.           * </pre>
    113. 

  113.           *
    114. 

  114.           * Using a join such as leftOuterJoin, the attribute names that are shared between
    115. 

  115.           * the tables are combined in the single return hash.  You can get around that by
    116. 

  116.           * using {@link patio.Dataset#select} with correct aliases for all of the columns, but it is simpler to
    117. 

  117.           * use {@link patio.Dataset#graph} and have the result set split for you.  In addition, {@link patio.Dataset#graph} respects
    118. 

  118.           * any {@link patio.Dataset#rowCb} of the current dataset and the datasets you use with {@link patio.Dataset#graph}.
    119. 

  119.           *
    120. 

  120.           * If you are graphing a table and all columns for that table are null, this
    121. 

  121.           * indicates that no matching rows existed in the table, so graph will return null.
    122. 

  122.           * instead of a hash with all nil values:
    123. 

  123.           *
    124. 

  124.           * <pre class="code">
    125. 

  125.           *   // Psuedo code there will be promises returned
    126. 

  126.           *   /// If the artist doesn't have any albums
    127. 

  127.           *
    128. 

  128.           *   var DB = patio.defaultDatabase, ds = db.from("artists");
    129. 

  129.           *   var obj = ds.graph(:albums, :artist_id=>:id).first()
    130. 

  130.           *   //obj == { artists : {id : artists.id, name : artists.name}, albums : null};
    131. 

  131.           * </pre>
    132. 

  132.           *
    133. 

  133.           *
    134. 

  134.           * @parameter {String|patio.Dataset|Object} dataset This can be a string (representing a table), another {@link patio.Dataset},
    135. 

  135.           *            or an object that has a dataset property that returns a string or dataset.
    136. 

  136.           * @parameter joinConditions Any condition(s) allowed by {@link patio.Dataset#joinTable}.
    137. 

  137.           *
    138. 

  138.           * @parameter {Object} [options] options to use when creating the graph
    139. 

  139.           *
    140. 

  140.           * @parameter {String|sql.LiteralString|sql.Identifier} [options.fromSelfAlias] The alias to use when the
    141. 

  141.           *                      receiver is not a graphed dataset but it contains multiple FROM tables or a JOIN.
    142. 

  142.           *                      In this case, the receiver is wrapped in a {@link patio.Dataset#fromSelf} before graphing,
    143. 

  143.           *                      and this option determines the alias to use.
    144. 

  144.           * @parameter {String|sql.LiteralString|sql.Identifier} [options.implicitQualifier] The qualifier of implicit conditions,
    145. 

  145.           *              see {@link patio.Dataset#joinTable}.
    146. 

  146.           * @parameter [String] [options.joinType="leftOuter"] The type of join to use (passed to {@link patio.Dataset#joinTable}.).
    147. 

  147.           * @parameter [String[]|sql.LiteralString[]|sql.Identifier[]|Boolean] [options.select] An array of columns to select.  When not used, selects
    148. 

  148.           *            all columns in the given dataset.  When set to false, selects no
    149. 

  149.           *            columns and is like simply joining the tables, though graph keeps
    150. 

  150.           *            some metadata about the join that makes it important to use {@link patio.Dataset#graph} instead
    151. 

  151.           *            of {@link patio.Dataset#joinTable}
    152. 

  152.           * @parameter {String|sql.LiteralString|sql.Identifier} [options.tableAlias] The alias to use for the table.  If not specified, doesn't
    153. 

  153.           *                 alias the table.  You will get an error if the the alias (or table) name is
    154. 

  154.           *                 used more than once.
    155. 

  155.  
    156. 

  156.           * @parameter {Function} block  A function that is passed to {@link patio.Dataset#joinTable}.
    157. 

  157.           **/
    158. 

  158.          graph:function (dataset, joinConditions, options, block) {
    159. 

  159. 52            var ret = new Promise();
    160. 

  160. 52            var args = argsToArray(arguments, 1);
    161. 

  161. 52            block = isFunction(args[args.length - 1]) ? args.pop() : null;
    162. 

  162. 52            joinConditions = args.shift() || null;
    163. 

  163. 52            options = args.shift() || {};
    164. 

  164.              // Allow the use of a model, dataset, or string as the first argument
    165. 

  165.              // Find the table name/dataset based on the argument
    166. 

  166. 52            dataset.hasOwnProperty("dataset") && (dataset = dataset.dataset);
    167. 

  167. 52            var tableAlias = options.tableAlias, table;
    168. 

  168. 52            if (isString(dataset)) {
    169. 

  169. 18                table = sql.identifier(dataset);
    170. 

  170. 18                dataset = this.db.from(dataset);
    171. 

  171. 18                isUndefinedOrNull(tableAlias) && (tableAlias = table);
    172. 

  172. 34            } else if (isInstanceOf(dataset, Dataset)) {
    173. 

  173. 33                if (dataset.isSimpleSelectAll) {
    174. 

  174. 29                    table = dataset.__opts.from[0];
    175. 

  175. 29                    isUndefinedOrNull(tableAlias) && (tableAlias = table);
    176. 

  176.                  } else {
    177. 

  177. 4                    table = dataset;
    178. 

  178. 4                    isUndefinedOrNull(tableAlias) && (tableAlias = this._datasetAlias((this.__opts.numDatasetSources || 0) + 1));
    179. 

  179.                  }
    180. 

  180.              } else {
    181. 

  181. 1                throw new QueryError("The dataset arg should be a string, dataset or model");
    182. 

  182.              }
    183. 

  183.  
    184. 

  184. 51            var aliases;
    185. 

  185.              // Only allow table aliases that haven't been used
    186. 

  186. 51            var thisOpts = this.__opts, thisOptsGraph = thisOpts.graph;
    187. 

  187. 51            if (isObject(thisOptsGraph) && isHash((aliases = thisOptsGraph.tableAliases)) && !isUndefinedOrNull(aliases[tableAlias.value])) {
    188. 

  188. 1                raiseAliasError(options);
    189. 

  189.              }
    190. 

  190.              // Use a from_self if this is already a joined table
    191. 

  191. 50            var ds = (!thisOptsGraph && (thisOpts.from.length > 1 || thisOpts.join)) ? this.fromSelf({alias:options.fromSelfAlias || this.firstSourceAlias}) : this;
    192. 

  192.  
    193. 

  193.              // Join the table early in order to avoid cloning the dataset twice
    194. 

  194. 50            ds = ds.joinTable(options.joinType || "leftOuter", table, joinConditions, {tableAlias:tableAlias, implicitQualifier:options.implicitQualifier}, block);
    195. 

  195. 50            var opts = ds.__opts;
    196. 

  196.  
    197. 

  197.              // Whether to include the table in the result set
    198. 

  198. 50            var addTable = isBoolean(options.select) ? options.select : true;
    199. 

  199.              // Whether to add the columns to the list of column aliases
    200. 

  200. 50            var addColumns = isUndefinedOrNull(opts.graphAliases);
    201. 

  201.              // Setup the initial graph data structure if it doesn't exist
    202. 

  202. 50            var graph;
    203. 

  203. 50            var populateGraphPromise = new Promise();
    204. 

  204. 50            if (isUndefinedOrNull((graph = opts.graph))) {
    205. 

  205. 41                var master = this._toTableName(ds.firstSourceAlias);
    206. 

  206. 41                (master == tableAlias) && raiseAliasError(options);
    207. 

  207.                  // Master hash storing all .graph related information
    208. 

  208. 40                graph = opts.graph = {};
    209. 

  209.                  // Associates column aliases back to tables and columns
    210. 

  210. 40                var columnAliases = graph.columnAliases = {};
    211. 

  211.                  // Associates table alias (the master is never aliased)
    212. 

  212. 40                var tableAliases = graph.tableAliases = {};
    213. 

  213. 40                tableAliases[master] = this;
    214. 

  214.  
    215. 

  215.                  // All columns in the master table are never
    216. 

  216.                  // aliased, but are not included if set_graph_aliases
    217. 

  217.                  // has been used.
    218. 

  218. 40                if (addColumns) {
    219. 

  219. 39                    var select = opts.select = [];
    220. 

  220. 39                    this.columns.then(hitch(this, function (cols) {
    221. 

  221. 39                        cols.forEach(function (column) {
    222. 

  222. 113                            columnAliases[column] = [master, column];
    223. 

  223. 113                            select.push(new sql.QualifiedIdentifier(master, column));
    224. 

  224.                          });
    225. 

  225. 39                        populateGraphPromise.callback(graph);
    226. 

  226.                      }), ret);
    227. 

  227.                  } else {
    228. 

  228. 1                    populateGraphPromise.callback(graph);
    229. 

  229.                  }
    230. 

  230.              } else {
    231. 

  231. 9                populateGraphPromise.callback(graph);
    232. 

  232.              }
    233. 

  233. 49            populateGraphPromise.then(hitch(this, function (graph) {
    234. 

  234.                  // Add the table alias to the list of aliases
    235. 

  235.                  // Even if it isn't been used in the result set,
    236. 

  236.                  // we add a key for it with a nil value so we can check if it
    237. 

  237.                  // is used more than once
    238. 

  238. 49                var tableAliases = graph.tableAliases;
    239. 

  239. 49                tableAliases[tableAlias] = addTable ? dataset : null;
    240. 

  240.  
    241. 

  241.                  // Add the columns to the selection unless we are ignoring them
    242. 

  242. 49                if (addTable && addColumns) {
    243. 

  243. 46                    var select = opts.select;
    244. 

  244. 46                    var columnAliases = graph.columnAliases;
    245. 

  245.  
    246. 

  246.                      // Which columns to add to the result set
    247. 

  247. 46                    var dsColPromise;
    248. 

  248. 46                    if (options.select) {
    249. 

  249. 1                        dsColPromise = new Promise().callback(options.select);
    250. 

  250.                      } else {
    251. 

  251. 45                        dsColPromise = dataset.columns;
    252. 

  252.                      }
    253. 

  253.                      // If the column hasn't been used yet, don't alias it.
    254. 

  254.                      // If it has been used, try tableColumn.
    255. 

  255. 46                    dsColPromise.then(hitch(this, function (cols) {
    256. 

  256. 46                        cols.forEach(function (column) {
    257. 

  257. 182                            var colAlias, identifier;
    258. 

  258. 182                            if (columnAliases[column]) {
    259. 

  259. 135                                var columnAlias = format("%s_%s", [tableAlias, column]);
    260. 

  260. 135                                colAlias = columnAlias;
    261. 

  261. 135                                identifier = new sql.QualifiedIdentifier(tableAlias, column).as(columnAlias);
    262. 

  262.                              } else {
    263. 

  263. 47                                colAlias = column;
    264. 

  264. 47                                identifier = new sql.QualifiedIdentifier(tableAlias, column);
    265. 

  265.                              }
    266. 

  266. 182                            columnAliases[colAlias] = [tableAlias, column];
    267. 

  267. 182                            select.push(identifier);
    268. 

  268.                          });
    269. 

  269. 46                        ret.callback(ds);
    270. 

  270.                      }), ret);
    271. 

  271.                  } else {
    272. 

  272. 3                    ret.callback(ds);
    273. 

  273.                  }
    274. 

  274.              }), ret);
    275. 

  275. 49            return ret.promise();
    276. 

  276.          },
    277. 

  277.  
    278. 

  278.  
    279. 

  279.          /**
    280. 

  280.           * This allows you to manually specify the graph aliases to use
    281. 

  281.           * when using graph.  You can use it to only select certain
    282. 

  282.           * columns, and have those columns mapped to specific aliases
    283. 

  283.           * in the result set.  This is the equivalent of {@link patio.Dataset#select} for a
    284. 

  284.           * graphed dataset, and must be used instead of {@link patio.Dataset#select} whenever
    285. 

  285.           * graphing is used.
    286. 

  286.           *
    287. 

  287.           * @example
    288. 

  288.           *
    289. 

  289.           * var DB = patio.defaultDatabase, ds = DB.from("artists");
    290. 

  290.           * var p = comb.executeInOrder(ds, function(ds){
    291. 

  291.           *     var graphedDs = ds.graph("albums", {artist_id : id});
    292. 

  292.           *     //SELECT artists.name AS artist_name, albums.name AS album_name, 42 AS forty_two FROM table
    293. 

  293.           *     return graphedDs.setGraphAliases({artist_name : ["artists", "name"],
    294. 

  294.           *                       album_name : ["albums", "name"],
    295. 

  295.           *                       forty_two : ["albums", "fourtwo", 42]).first();
    296. 

  296.           * });
    297. 

  297.           *
    298. 

  298.           * p.then(function(obj){
    299. 

  299.           *    //obj == {artists : {name : artists.name}, albums : {name : albums.name, fourtwo : 42}}
    300. 

  300.           * });
    301. 

  301.           *
    302. 

  302.           * @parameter {Object} graphAliases Should be a hash with keys being  column aliases, and values being
    303. 

  303.           *                  arrays with two or three elements. The first element of the array should be the table alias,
    304. 

  304.           *                  and the second should be the actual column name. If the array
    305. 

  305.           *                  has a third element, it is used as the value returned, instead of
    306. 

  306.           *                  tableAlias.columnName.
    307. 

  307.           *
    308. 

  308.           **/
    309. 

  309.          setGraphAliases:function (graphAliases) {
    310. 

  310. 10            var ds = this.select.apply(this, this.__graphAliasColumns(graphAliases));
    311. 

  311. 10            ds.__opts.graphAliases = graphAliases;
    312. 

  312. 10            return ds;
    313. 

  313.          },
    314. 

  314.  
    315. 

  315.  
    316. 

  316.          /**
    317. 

  317.           * Remove the splitting of results into subhashes, and all metadata
    318. 

  318.           * related to the current graph (if any).
    319. 

  319.           */
    320. 

  320.          ungraphed:function () {
    321. 

  321. 237            return this.mergeOptions({graph:null});
    322. 

  322.          },
    323. 

  323.  
    324. 

  324.          //Transform the hash of graph aliases to an array of columns
    325. 

  325.          __graphAliasColumns:function (graphAliases) {
    326. 

  326. 13            var ret = [];
    327. 

  327. 13            if (isArray(graphAliases)) {
    328. 

  328. 1                var newGraphAliases = {};
    329. 

  329. 1                for (var i in graphAliases) {
    330. 

  330. 2                    newGraphAliases[graphAliases[i][0]] = graphAliases[i][1];
    331. 

  331.                  }
    332. 

  332. 1                graphAliases = newGraphAliases;
    333. 

  333.              }
    334. 

  334. 13            for (var colAlias in graphAliases) {
    335. 

  335. 20                var tc = graphAliases[colAlias];
    336. 

  336. 20                var identifier = tc[2] || new sql.QualifiedIdentifier(tc[0], tc[1]);
    337. 

  337. 20                if (tc[2] || tc[1] != colAlias) {
    338. 

  338. 10                    identifier = new sql.AliasedExpression(identifier, colAlias);
    339. 

  339.                  }
    340. 

  340. 20                ret.push(identifier);
    341. 

  341.              }
    342. 

  342. 13            return ret;
    343. 

  343.          },
    344. 

  344.  
    345. 

  345.  
    346. 

  346.          /**
    347. 

  347.           * Fetch the rows, split them into component table parts,
    348. 

  348.           * transform and run the {@link patio.Dataset#rowCb} on each part (if applicable),
    349. 

  349.           * and yield a hash of the parts.
    350. 

  350.           * */
    351. 

  351.          graphEach:function (cb) {
    352. 

  352.              // Reject tables with nil datasets, as they are excluded from
    353. 

  353.              // the result set
    354. 

  354. 12            var datasets = toArray(this.__opts.graph.tableAliases).filter(function (e) {
    355. 

  355. 28                return !isUndefinedOrNull(e[1]);
    356. 

  356.              });
    357. 

  357.              // Get just the list of table aliases into a local variable, for speed
    358. 

  358. 12            var tableAliases = datasets.map(function (e) {
    359. 

  359. 27                return e[0];
    360. 

  360.              });
    361. 

  361.  
    362. 

  362. 12            datasets = datasets.map(function (e) {
    363. 

  363. 27                return [e[0], e[1], e[1].rowCb]
    364. 

  364.              });
    365. 

  365.              // Use the manually set graph aliases, if any, otherwise
    366. 

  366.              // use the ones automatically created by .graph
    367. 

  367. 12            var columnAliases = this.__opts.graphAliases || this.__opts.graph.columnAliases;
    368. 

  368. 12            var ret = this.fetchRows(this.selectSql).map(function (r) {
    369. 

  369. 15                var graph = {};
    370. 

  370.                  // Create the sub hashes, one per table
    371. 

  371. 15                tableAliases.forEach(function (ta) {
    372. 

  372. 36                    graph[ta] = {};
    373. 

  373.                  });
    374. 

  374.                  // Split the result set based on the column aliases
    375. 

  375.                  // If there are columns in the result set that are
    376. 

  376.                  // not in column_aliases, they are ignored
    377. 

  377. 15                for (var colAlias in columnAliases) {
    378. 

  378. 114                    var tc = columnAliases[colAlias];
    379. 

  379. 114                    var ta = tc[0], column = tc[1];
    380. 

  380. 114                    !graph[ta] && (graph[ta] = {});
    381. 

  381. 114                    graph[ta][column] = r[colAlias];
    382. 

  382.                  }
    383. 

  383. 15                datasets.forEach(function (d) {
    384. 

  384. 36                    var ta = d[0], ds = d[1], dsCb = d[2];
    385. 

  385. 36                    var g = graph[ta];
    386. 

  386. 36                    if (!isEmpty(g) && Object.keys(g).some(function (x) {
    387. 

  387. 49                        return !isUndefinedOrNull(g[x]);
    388. 

  388.                      })) {
    389. 

  389. 30                        graph[ta] = dsCb ? dsCb(g) : g;
    390. 

  390.                      } else {
    391. 

  391. 6                        graph[ta] = null;
    392. 

  392.                      }
    393. 

  393.                  });
    394. 

  394. 15                return graph;
    395. 

  395.              });
    396. 

  396. 12            if (cb) {
    397. 

  397. 0                ret.forEach(cb);
    398. 

  398.              }
    399. 

  399. 12            return ret;
    400. 

  400.          }
    401. 

  401.      }
    402. 

  402.  }).as(module);

database/dataset.js
Coverage100.00 SLOC107 LOC19 Missed0 
  1. 1var comb = require("comb"),
    2. 

  2.      define = comb.define,
    3. 

  3.      argsToArray = comb.argsToArray,
    4. 

  4.      isFunction = comb.isFunction,
    5. 

  5.      hitch = comb.hitch,
    6. 

  6.      errors = require("../errors"),
    7. 

  7.      NotImplemented = errors.NotImplemented,
    8. 

  8.      Promise = comb.Promise,
    9. 

  9.      Dataset = require("../dataset");
    10. 

  10.  
    11. 

  11. 1var Database = define(null, {
    12. 

  12.      instance:{
    13. 

  13.          /**@lends patio.Database.prototype*/
    14. 

  14.          /**
    15. 

  15.           *Fetches records for an arbitrary SQL statement. If a block is given,
    16. 

  16.           * it is used to iterate over the records:
    17. 

  17.           * <pre class="code">
    18. 

  18.           *   DB.fetch('SELECT * FROM items', function(r){
    19. 

  19.           *      //do something with row
    20. 

  20.           *   });
    21. 

  21.           *</pre>
    22. 

  22.           * If a block is not given then {@link patio.Database#fetch} method returns a {@link patio.Dataset} instance:
    23. 

  23.           * <pre class="code">
    24. 

  24.           *   DB.fetch('SELECT * FROM items').all().then(function(records){
    25. 

  25.           *      //do something with the records.
    26. 

  26.           *   });
    27. 

  27.           * </pre>
    28. 

  28.           *
    29. 

  29.           * {@link patio.Database#fetch} can also perform parameterized queries for protection against SQL
    30. 

  30.           * injection:
    31. 

  31.           * <pre class="code">
    32. 

  32.           *   DB.fetch('SELECT * FROM items WHERE name = ?', myName).all().then(function(records){
    33. 

  33.           *      //do something with the records.
    34. 

  34.           *   });
    35. 

  35.           * </pre>
    36. 

  36.           *
    37. 

  37.           * @param {String...} args variable number of args where the first argument is a String. If more than
    38. 

  38.           * one argument is given then the SQL will be treated as a place holder string. See {@link patio.Dataset#withSql}.
    39. 

  39.           * @param {Function} [block=null] if the last argument given is a function then {@link patio.Dataset#forEach} will be
    40. 

  40.           * invoked on the dataset with the block called for each row.
    41. 

  41.           *
    42. 

  42.           * @return {Promise|patio.Dataset} if no block is given then a {@link patio.Dataset} will be returned. If a block
    43. 

  43.           * is given then the return value will be a Promise that will be invoked after all records have been returned
    44. 

  44.           * and processed through the block.
    45. 

  45.           * */
    46. 

  46.          fetch:function (args, block) {
    47. 

  47. 23            var ret = new Promise();
    48. 

  48. 23            args = argsToArray(arguments);
    49. 

  49. 23            block = isFunction(args[args.length - 1]) ? args.pop() : null;
    50. 

  50. 23            var ds = this.dataset.withSql.apply(this.dataset, args);
    51. 

  51. 23            if (block) {
    52. 

  52. 3                ds.forEach(block).then(function () {
    53. 

  53. 3                    ret.callback(ds);
    54. 

  54.                  }, ret);
    55. 

  55. 3                return ret.promise();
    56. 

  56.              } else {
    57. 

  57. 20                return ds;
    58. 

  58.              }
    59. 

  59.          },
    60. 

  60.  
    61. 

  61.          /**
    62. 

  62.           * Returns a new {@link patio.Dataset} with the [@link patio.Dataset#from} method invoked. If a block is given,
    63. 

  63.           * it is used as a filter(see {@link patio.Dataset#filter} on the dataset.
    64. 

  64.           * @example
    65. 

  65.           *   DB.from("items").sql //=> SELECT * FROM items
    66. 

  66.           *   DB.from("items", function(){
    67. 

  67.           *          return this.id.gt(2)
    68. 

  68.           *   }).sql; //=> SELECT * FROM items WHERE (id > 2)
    69. 

  69.           * @param {String...} args table/s to pass to {@link patio.Dataset#from} with.
    70. 

  70.           * @param {function} [block] an option block to pass to {@link patio.Dataset#filter} with.
    71. 

  71.           *
    72. 

  72.           * @return {patio.Dataset} a dataset to use for querying the {@link patio.Database} with.
    73. 

  73.           * */
    74. 

  74.          from:function (args, block) {
    75. 

  75. 529            args = argsToArray(arguments);
    76. 

  76. 529            block = isFunction(args[args.length - 1]) ? args.pop() : null;
    77. 

  77. 529            var ds = this.dataset;
    78. 

  78. 529            ds = ds.from.apply(ds, args);
    79. 

  79. 529            return block ? ds.filter(block) : ds;
    80. 

  80.          },
    81. 

  81.  
    82. 

  82.          /**
    83. 

  83.           * Returns a new {@link patio.Dataset} with the {@link patio.Dataset#select} method invoked.
    84. 

  84.           * @example
    85. 

  85.           *   DB.select(1) //=> SELECT 1
    86. 

  86.           *   DB.select(function(){
    87. 

  87.           *      return this.server_version();
    88. 

  88.           *   }).sql; //=> SELECT server_version()
    89. 

  89.           *   DB.select("id").from("items").sql; //=> SELECT id FROM items
    90. 

  90.           * @link {patio.Dataset} a dataset to query the {@link patio.Database} with.
    91. 

  91.           **/
    92. 

  92.          select:function () {
    93. 

  93. 2            var ds = this.dataset;
    94. 

  94. 2            return ds.select.apply(ds, arguments);
    95. 

  95.          },
    96. 

  96.  
    97. 

  97.          /**@ignore*/
    98. 

  98.          getters:{
    99. 

  99.              dataset:function () {
    100. 

  100. 10                return new Dataset(this);
    101. 

  101.              }
    102. 

  102.          }
    103. 

  103.  
    104. 

  104.      }
    105. 

  105.  }).as(module);
    106. 

  106.  
    107. 

  107.

plugins/cache.js

  1. 1var comb = require("comb"),
    2. 

  2.      hitch = comb.hitch,
    3. 

  3.      Promise = comb.Promise,
    4. 

  4.      PromiseList = comb.PromiseList,
    5. 

  5.      Hive = require("hive-cache");
    6. 

  6.  
    7. 

  7.  
    8. 

  8. 1var hive;
    9. 

  9. 1var i = 0;
    10. 

  10.  
    11. 

  11. 1var LOGGER = comb.logging.Logger.getLogger("patio.plugins.CachePlugin");
    12. 

  12.  /**
    13. 

  13.   * @class Adds in memory caching support for models.
    14. 

  14.   *
    15. 

  15.   * @example
    16. 

  16.   *
    17. 

  17.   * var MyModel = patio.addModel("testTable", {
    18. 

  18.   *     plugins : [patio.plugins.CachePlugin];
    19. 

  19.   * });
    20. 

  20.   *
    21. 

  21.   * //NOW IT WILL CACHE
    22. 

  22.   *
    23. 

  23.   * @name CachePlugin
    24. 

  24.   * @memberOf patio.plugins
    25. 

  25.   */
    26. 

  26. 1exports.CachePlugin = comb.define(null, {
    27. 

  27.      instance:{
    28. 

  28.  
    29. 

  29.          constructor:function () {
    30. 

  30. 6            this._super(arguments);
    31. 

  31. 6            this.post("load", this._postLoad);
    32. 

  32. 6            this._static.initHive();
    33. 

  33.          },
    34. 

  34.  
    35. 

  35.          reload:function () {
    36. 

  36. 1            var ret = new Promise();
    37. 

  37. 1            this._super(arguments).then(hitch(this, function (m) {
    38. 

  38. 1                hive.replace((this.tableName.toString() + this.primaryKeyValue.toString()), m);
    39. 

  39. 1                ret.callback(m);
    40. 

  40.              }), ret);
    41. 

  41. 1            return ret.promise();
    42. 

  42.          },
    43. 

  43.  
    44. 

  44.          _postLoad:function (next) {
    45. 

  45. 25            hive.replace(this.tableName + this.primaryKeyValue, this);
    46. 

  46. 25            next();
    47. 

  47.          },
    48. 

  48.  
    49. 

  49.          update:function (options, errback) {
    50. 

  50. 1            var ret = new Promise();
    51. 

  51. 1            this._super(arguments).then(hitch(this, function (val) {
    52. 

  52. 1                hive.remove(this.tableName + this.primaryKeyValue, val);
    53. 

  53. 1                ret.callback(val);
    54. 

  54.              }), ret);
    55. 

  55. 1            return ret.promise();
    56. 

  56.          },
    57. 

  57.  
    58. 

  58.          remove:function (errback) {
    59. 

  59. 1            hive.remove(this.tableName + this.primaryKeyValue);
    60. 

  60. 1            return this._super(arguments);
    61. 

  61.          }
    62. 

  62.      },
    63. 

  63.  
    64. 

  64.      static:{
    65. 

  65.          initHive:function () {
    66. 

  66. 6            if (!hive) {
    67. 

  67. 1                hive = new Hive();
    68. 

  68.              }
    69. 

  69. 6            this.cache = hive;
    70. 

  70.          },
    71. 

  71.  
    72. 

  72.          findById:function (id) {
    73. 

  73. 3            var cached = hive.get(this.tableName + id);
    74. 

  74. 3            if (!cached) {
    75. 

  75. 1                return this._super(arguments);
    76. 

  76.              } else {
    77. 

  77. 2                var ret = new Promise();
    78. 

  78. 2                ret.callback(cached);
    79. 

  79. 2                return ret;
    80. 

  80.              }
    81. 

  81.          }
    82. 

  82.      }
    83. 

  83.  });
plugins/columnMapper.js
Coverage100.00 SLOC192 LOC44 Missed0 
  1. 1var comb = require("comb"),
    2. 

  2.      toArray = comb.array.toArray,
    3. 

  3.      isInstanceOf = comb.isInstanceOf,
    4. 

  4.      isBoolean = comb.isBoolean,
    5. 

  5.      when = comb.when,
    6. 

  6.      isHash = comb.isHash,
    7. 

  7.      isString = comb.isString,
    8. 

  8.      sql = require("../sql.js").sql,
    9. 

  9.      AliasedExpression = sql.AliasedExpression,
    10. 

  10.      Identifier = sql.Identifier,
    11. 

  11.      isConditionSpecifier = sql.Expression.isConditionSpecifier,
    12. 

  12.      ModelError = require("../errors.js").ModelError;
    13. 

  13.  
    14. 

  14.  
    15. 

  15.  /**
    16. 

  16.   * @class This plugin exposes the ability to map columns on other tables to this Model.
    17. 

  17.   *
    18. 

  18.   * See {@link patio.plugins.ColumnMapper.mappedColumn} for more information.
    19. 

  19.   *
    20. 

  20.   * @name ColumnMapper
    21. 

  21.   * @memberof patio.plugins
    22. 

  22.   *
    23. 

  23.   */
    24. 

  24. 1comb.define(null, {
    25. 

  25.  
    26. 

  26.      "static":{
    27. 

  27.  
    28. 

  28.          /**@lends patio.plugins.ColumnMapper*/
    29. 

  29.  
    30. 

  30.          /**
    31. 

  31.           * Boolean flag indicating if mapped columns should be re-fetched on update.
    32. 

  32.           *
    33. 

  33.           * <b>NOTE</b> This can be overridden by passing {reload : false} to the {@link patio.Model#update} method.
    34. 

  34.           * @default true
    35. 

  35.           */
    36. 

  36.          fetchMappedColumnsOnUpdate:true,
    37. 

  37.  
    38. 

  38.          /**
    39. 

  39.           * Boolean flag indicating if mapped columns should be re-fetched on save.
    40. 

  40.           *
    41. 

  41.           * <b>NOTE</b> This can be overridden by passing {reload : false} to the {@link patio.Model#save} method.
    42. 

  42.           * @default true
    43. 

  43.           */
    44. 

  44.          fetchMappedColumnsOnSave:true,
    45. 

  45.  
    46. 

  46.  
    47. 

  47.          /**
    48. 

  48.           * Add a mapped column from another table. This is useful if there columns on
    49. 

  49.           * another table but you do not want to load the association every time.
    50. 

  50.           *
    51. 

  51.           *
    52. 

  52.           * For example assume we have an employee and works table. Well we might want the salary from the works table,
    53. 

  53.           * but do not want to add it to the employee table.
    54. 

  54.           *
    55. 

  55.           * <b>NOTE:</b> mapped columns are READ ONLY.
    56. 

  56.           *
    57. 

  57.           * {@code
    58. 

  58.           * patio.addModel("employee")
    59. 

  59.           *    .oneToOne("works")
    60. 

  60.           *    .mappedColumn("salary", "works", {employeeId : patio.sql.identifier("id")});
    61. 

  61.           * }
    62. 

  62.           *
    63. 

  63.           * You can also change the name of the of the column
    64. 

  64.           *
    65. 

  65.           * {@code
    66. 

  66.           *  patio.addModel("employee")
    67. 

  67.           *    .oneToOne("works")
    68. 

  68.           *    .mappedColumn("mySalary", "works", {employeeId : patio.sql.identifier("id")}, {
    69. 

  69.           *          column : "salary"
    70. 

  70.           *    });
    71. 

  71.           * }
    72. 

  72.           *
    73. 

  73.           * If you want to prevent the mapped columns from being reloaded after a save or update you can set the
    74. 

  74.           * <code>fetchMappedColumnsOnUpdate</code> or <code>fetchMappedColumnsOnSave</code> to false.
    75. 

  75.           *
    76. 

  76.           * {@code
    77. 

  77.           *
    78. 

  78.           * var Employee = patio.addModel("employee")
    79. 

  79.           *   .oneToOne("works")
    80. 

  80.           *   .mappedColumn("mySalary", "works", {employeeId : patio.sql.identifier("id")}, {
    81. 

  81.           *          column : "salary"
    82. 

  82.           *   });
    83. 

  83.           *
    84. 

  84.           * //prevent the mapped columns from being fetched after a save.
    85. 

  85.           * Employee.fetchMappedColumnsOnSave = false;
    86. 

  86.           *
    87. 

  87.           * //prevent the mapped columns from being re-fetched after an update.
    88. 

  88.           * Employee.fetchMappedColumnsOnUpdate = false;
    89. 

  89.           * }
    90. 

  90.           *
    91. 

  91.           * You can also override prevent the properties from being reloaded by setting the <code>reload</code> or <code>reloadMapped</code> options when saving or updating.
    92. 

  92.           *
    93. 

  93.           * {@code
    94. 

  94.           * //prevents entire model from being reloaded including mapped columns
    95. 

  95.           * employee.save(null, {reload : false});
    96. 

  96.           * employee.update(null, {reload : false});
    97. 

  97.           *
    98. 

  98.           * //just prevents just the mapped columns from being reloaded
    99. 

  99.           * employee.save(null, {reloadMapped : false});
    100. 

  100.           * employee.update(null, {reloadMapped : false});
    101. 

  101.           * }
    102. 

  102.           *
    103. 

  103.           * @param {String} name the name you want the column represented as on the model.
    104. 

  104.           * @param {String|patio.Model} table the table or model you want the property mapped from
    105. 

  105.           * @param condition the join condition. See {@link patio.Dataset#joinTable}.
    106. 

  106.           * @param {Object} [opts={}] additional options
    107. 

  107.           * @param {String} [opts.joinType="left"] the join type to use when gathering the properties.
    108. 

  108.           * @param {String|patio.sql.Identifer} [opts.column=null] the column on the remote table that should be used
    109. 

  109.           * as the local copy.
    110. 

  110.           *
    111. 

  111.           * @return {patio.Model} returns the model for chaining.
    112. 

  112.           */
    113. 

  113.          mappedColumn:function (name, table, condition, opts) {
    114. 

  114. 6            opts = opts || {};
    115. 

  115. 6            if (name) {
    116. 

  116. 6                name = sql.stringToIdentifier(name);
    117. 

  117. 6                if (table && condition) {
    118. 

  118. 4                    opts = comb.merge({joinType:"left", table:table, condition:condition, column:name}, opts);
    119. 

  119. 4                    this._mappedColumns[name] = opts;
    120. 

  120.                  } else {
    121. 

  121. 2                    throw new ModelError("mapped column requires a table and join condition");
    122. 

  122.                  }
    123. 

  123.              }
    124. 

  124. 4            return this;
    125. 

  125.          },
    126. 

  126.  
    127. 

  127.          sync:function () {
    128. 

  128. 44            var ret = this._super(arguments);
    129. 

  129. 44            if (!this.synced) {
    130. 

  130. 1                ret = ret.chain(function () {
    131. 

  131. 1                    var ds = this.dataset.naked().select(), mappedColumns = this._mappedColumns, joinTableAlias = "columnMapper", selects = [];
    132. 

  132. 1                    Object.keys(mappedColumns).forEach(function (column, i) {
    133. 

  133. 4                        var opts = mappedColumns[column],
    134. 

  134.                              condition = opts.condition;
    135. 

  135. 4                        if (isConditionSpecifier(condition)) {
    136. 

  136. 4                            condition = toArray(condition);
    137. 

  137. 4                            condition.forEach(function (cond) {
    138. 

  138. 4                                var val = cond[1];
    139. 

  139. 4                                if (!isInstanceOf(val, AliasedExpression) && isInstanceOf(val, Identifier)) {
    140. 

  140. 4                                    cond[1] = val.qualify(this.tableName);
    141. 

  141.                                  }
    142. 

  142.                              }, this);
    143. 

  143. 4                            var tableAlias = sql.identifier(joinTableAlias + i);
    144. 

  144. 4                            ds = ds.joinTable(opts.joinType, opts.table, condition, {tableAlias:tableAlias});
    145. 

  145. 4                            selects.push(sql.stringToIdentifier(opts.column).qualify(tableAlias).as(column));
    146. 

  146.                          }
    147. 

  147.                      }, this);
    148. 

  148. 1                    ds = ds.select(selects);
    149. 

  149.  
    150. 

  150. 1                    var middleWare = function (next) {
    151. 

  151. 17                        ds.filter(this._getPrimaryKeyQuery()).qualify().one().then(function (vals) {
    152. 

  152. 17                            this.setValues(vals);
    153. 

  153.                          }.bind(this)).classic(next);
    154. 

  154.                      };
    155. 

  155.  
    156. 

  156. 1                    var self = this;
    157. 

  157. 1                    this.post("load", middleWare);
    158. 

  158. 1                    this.post("save", function (next, options) {
    159. 

  159. 9                        options = options || {};
    160. 

  160. 9                        if (self.fetchMappedColumnsOnSave &&
    161. 

  161.                              isBoolean(options.reload) ? options.reload :
    162. 

  162.                              isBoolean(options.reloadMapped) ? options.reloadMapped :
    163. 

  163.                                  self.reloadOnSave) {
    164. 

  164. 6                            middleWare.apply(this, arguments);
    165. 

  165.                          } else {
    166. 

  166. 3                            next();
    167. 

  167.                          }
    168. 

  168.                      });
    169. 

  169. 1                    this.post("update", function (next, options) {
    170. 

  170. 4                        options = options || {};
    171. 

  171. 4                        if (self.fetchMappedColumnsOnUpdate &&
    172. 

  172.                              isBoolean(options.reload) ? options.reload :
    173. 

  173.                              isBoolean(options.reloadMapped) ? options.reloadMapped :
    174. 

  174.                                  self.reloadOnUpdate) {
    175. 

  175. 1                            middleWare.apply(this, arguments);
    176. 

  176.                          } else {
    177. 

  177. 3                            next();
    178. 

  178.                          }
    179. 

  179.                      });
    180. 

  180.                  }.bind(this));
    181. 

  181.              }
    182. 

  182. 44            return ret;
    183. 

  183.          },
    184. 

  184.  
    185. 

  185.          init:function () {
    186. 

  186. 2            this._super(arguments);
    187. 

  187. 2            this._mappedColumns = {};
    188. 

  188.          }
    189. 

  189.  
    190. 

  190.      }
    191. 

  191.  
    192. 

  192.  }).as(module);

    92. 

  92.          constructor:function () {
    93. 

  93. 21            this._super(arguments);
    94. 

  94. 21            var options = (this._timestampOptions = this._static._timestampOptions);
    95. 

  95. 21            this._updateColumn = options.updated || "updated";
    96. 

  96. 21            this._createdColumn = options.created || "created";
    97. 

  97. 21            this._updateOnCreate = options.updateOnCreate || false;
    98. 

  98.          },
    99. 

  99.  
    100. 

  100.          getInsertSql:function () {
    101. 

  101. 3            this[this._createdColumn] = new Date();
    102. 

  102. 3            if (this._updateOnCreate) {
    103. 

  103. 1                this[this._updateColumn] = new Date();
    104. 

  104.              }
    105. 

  105. 3            return this._super(arguments);
    106. 

  106.          },
    107. 

  107.  
    108. 

  108.          getUpdateSql:function () {
    109. 

  109. 3            this[this._updateColumn] = new Date();
    110. 

  110. 3            return this._super(arguments);
    111. 

  111.          }
    112.

    113.

  114.      static:{
    115. 

  115.          /**@lends patio.plugins.TimeStampPlugin*/
    116. 

  116.  
    117. 

  117.          /**
    118. 

  118.           * Adds timestamp functionality to a table.
    119. 

  119.           * @param {Object} [options]
    120. 

  120.           * @param {String} [options.updated="updated"] the name of the column to set the updated timestamp on.
    121. 

  121.           * @param {String} [options.created="created"] the name of the column to set the created timestamp on
    122. 

  122.           * @param {Boolean} [options.updateOnCreate=false] Set to true to set the updated column on creation
    123. 

  123.           **/
    124. 

  124.          timestamp:function (options) {
    125. 

  125. 3            options = options || {};
    126. 

  126. 3            this._timestampOptions = options;
    127. 

  127. 3            var updateColumn = options.updated || "updated";
    128. 

  128. 3            var createdColumn = options.created || "created";
    129. 

  129. 3            var updateOnCreate = options.updateOnCreate || false;
    130. 

  130. 3            this.pre("save", function (next) {
    131. 

  131. 12                this[createdColumn] = new Date();
    132. 

  132. 12                if (updateOnCreate) {
    133. 

  133. 4                    this[updateColumn] = new Date();
    134. 

  134.                  }
    135. 

  135. 12                next();
    136. 

  136.              });
    137. 

  137. 3            this.pre("update", function (next) {
    138. 

  138. 3                this[updateColumn] = new Date();
    139. 

  139. 3                next();
    140. 

  140.              });
    141. 

  141. 3            return this;
    142. 

  142.          }
    143. 

  143.      }

    180.

    182.

    187.

  188.          ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR:"yy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ssZ",
    189. 

  189.  
    190. 

  190.          /**
    191. 

  191.           * @type Boolean
    192. 

  192.           *
    193. 

  193.           * @description By default patio will try to covert all two digit years.
    194. 

  194.           * To turn this off:
    195. 

  195.           *
    196. 

  196.           * @default true
    197. 

  197.           *
    198. 

  198.           * @example
    199.

    200. 

  200.           */
    201. 

  201.          convertTwoDigitYears:true,
    202. 

  202.  
    203. 

  203.          __dateFormat:undefined,
    204. 

  204.          __yearFormat:undefined,
    205. 

  205.          __timeFormat:undefined,
    206. 

  206.          __timeStampFormat:undefined,
    207. 

  207.          __dateTimeFormat:undefined,
    208. 

  208.  
    209. 

  209.          /**
    210. 

  210.           * Converts a {@link patio.sql.Year} to a string.
    211. 

  211.           * The format used is {@link patio.Time#yearFormat},
    212. 

  212.           * which defaults to {@link patio.Time#DEFAULT_YEAR_FORMAT}
    213. 

  213.           *
    214. 

  214.           * @example
    215. 

  215.           *
    216. 

  216.           * var date = new Date(2004, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1),
    217. 

  217.           *     year = new sql.Year(2004);
    218. 

  218.           * patio.yearToString(date); //=> '2004'
    219. 

  219.           * patio.yearToString(year); //=> '2004'
    220. 

  220.           * patio.yearFormat = "yy";
    221. 

  221.           * patio.yearToString(date); //=> '04'
    222. 

  222.           * patio.yearToString(year); //=> '04'
    223. 

  223.           *
    224. 

  224.           *
    225. 

  225.           * @param {Date\sql.Year} dt the year to covert to to a string.
    226. 

  226.           *
    227. 

  227.           * @returns {String} the date string.
    228. 

  228.           */
    229. 

  229.          yearToString:function (dt, format) {
    230. 

  230. 8            return dateFormat(isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.Year) ? dt.date : dt, format || this.yearFormat);
    231. 

  231.          },
    232. 

  232.  
    233. 

  233.          /**
    234. 

  234.           * Converts a {@link sql.Time} to a string.
    235. 

  235.           * The format used is {@link patio.Time#timeFormat},
    236. 

  236.           * which defaults to {@link patio.Time#DEFAULT_TIME_FORMAT}
    237. 

  237.           *
    238. 

  238.           * @example
    239. 

  239.           *
    240. 

  240.           * var date =  new Date(null, null, null, 13, 12, 12),
    241. 

  241.           *     time = new sql.Time(13,12,12);
    242. 

  242.           * patio.timeToString(date); //=> '13:12:12'
    243. 

  243.           * patio.timeToString(time); //=> '13:12:12'
    244. 

  244.           * patio.timeFormat = "hh:mm:ss";
    245. 

  245.           * patio.timeToString(date); //=> '01:12:12'
    246. 

  246.           * patio.timeToString(time); //=> '01:12:12'
    247. 

  247.           *
    248. 

  248.           * @param {Date\patio.sql.Time} dt the time to covert to to a string.
    249. 

  249.           *
    250. 

  250.           * @returns {String} the date string.
    251. 

  251.           */
    252. 

  252.          timeToString:function (dt, format) {
    253. 

  253. 6            return dateFormat(isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.Time) ? dt.date : dt, format || this.timeFormat);
    254. 

  254.          },
    255. 

  255.  
    256. 

  256.          /**
    257. 

  257.           * Converts a @link{patio.sql.DateTime} to a string.
    258. 

  258.           * The format used is {@link patio.Time#dateTimeFormat},
    259. 

  259.           * which defaults to {@link patio.Time#DEFAULT_DATETIME_FORMAT}
    260. 

  260.           *
    261. 

  261.           * @example
    262. 

  262.           *
    263. 

  263.           * var date = new Date(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    264. 

  264.           * dateTime = new sql.DateTime(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    265. 

  265.           * offset = "-0600";
    266. 

  266.           * patio.dateTimeToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    267. 

  267.           * patio.dateTimeToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    268. 

  268.           *
    269. 

  269.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DATETIME_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    270. 

  270.           * patio.dateTimeToString(date); //=> '04-02-01 12:12:12'
    271. 

  271.           * patio.dateTimeToString(dateTime); //=> '04-02-01 12:12:12'
    272. 

  272.           *
    273. 

  273.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DATETIME_FORMAT_TZ;
    274. 

  274.           * patio.dateTimeToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'
    275. 

  275.           * patio.dateTimeToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'
    276. 

  276.           *
    277. 

  277.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.ISO_8601;
    278. 

  278.           * patio.dateTimeToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    279. 

  279.           * patio.dateTimeToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    280. 

  280.           *
    281. 

  281.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR;
    282. 

  282.           * patio.dateTimeToString(date); //=> '04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    283. 

  283.           * patio.dateTimeToString(dateTime); //=> '04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    284. 

  284.           *
    285. 

  285.           * @param {Date\patio.sql.DateTime} dt the datetime to covert to to a string.
    286. 

  286.           *
    287. 

  287.           * @returns {String} the date string.
    288. 

  288.           */
    289. 

  289.          dateTimeToString:function (dt, format) {
    290. 

  290. 46            return dateFormat(isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.DateTime) ? dt.date : dt, format || this.dateTimeFormat);
    291. 

  291.          },
    292. 

  292.  
    293. 

  293.  
    294. 

  294.          /**
    295. 

  295.           * Converts a {@link patio.sql.TimeStamp} to a string.
    296. 

  296.           * The format used is {@link patio.Time#timeStampFormat},
    297. 

  297.           * which defaults to {@link patio.Time#DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT}
    298. 

  298.           *
    299. 

  299.           * @example
    300. 

  300.           *
    301. 

  301.           * var date = new Date(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    302. 

  302.           * dateTime = new sql.TimeStamp(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    303. 

  303.           * offset = "-0600";
    304. 

  304.           * patio.timeStampToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    305. 

  305.           * patio.timeStampToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    306. 

  306.           *
    307. 

  307.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.TIMESTAMP_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    308. 

  308.           * patio.timeStampToString(date); //=> '04-02-01 12:12:12'
    309. 

  309.           * patio.timeStampToString(dateTime); //=> '04-02-01 12:12:12'
    310. 

  310.           *
    311. 

  311.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.TIMESTAMP_FORMAT_TZ;
    312. 

  312.           * patio.timeStampToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'
    313. 

  313.           * patio.timeStampToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'
    314. 

  314.           *
    315. 

  315.           * patio.timeStamp = patio.ISO_8601;
    316. 

  316.           * patio.timeStampToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    317. 

  317.           * patio.timeStampToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    318. 

  318.           *
    319. 

  319.           * patio.timeStamp = patio.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR;
    320. 

  320.           * patio.timeStampToString(date); //=> '04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    321. 

  321.           * patio.timeStampToString(dateTime); //=> '04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    322. 

  322.           *
    323. 

  323.           *
    324. 

  324.           * @param {Date\patio.sql.TimeStamp} dt the timestamp to convert to to a string.
    325. 

  325.           *
    326. 

  326.           * @returns {String} the date string.
    327. 

  327.           */
    328. 

  328.          timeStampToString:function (dt, format) {
    329. 

  329. 21            return dateFormat(isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.TimeStamp) ? dt.date : dt, format || this.timeStampFormat);
    330. 

  330.          },
    331. 

  331.  
    332. 

  332.          /**
    333. 

  333.           * Converts a date to a string.
    334. 

  334.           *
    335. 

  335.           * @example
    336. 

  336.           *
    337. 

  337.           * var date = new Date(2004, 1, 1),
    338. 

  338.           * timeStamp = new sql.TimeStamp(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    339. 

  339.           * dateTime = new sql.DateTime(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    340. 

  340.           * year = new sql.Year(2004),
    341. 

  341.           * time = new sql.Time(12,12,12),
    342. 

  342.           *
    343. 

  343.           * //convert years
    344. 

  344.           * patio.dateToString(year); //=> '2004'
    345. 

  345.           * patio.yearFormat = "yy";
    346. 

  346.           * patio.dateToString(year); //=> '04'
    347. 

  347.           * patio.yearFormat = patio.DEFAULT_YEAR_FORMAT;
    348. 

  348.           * patio.dateToString(year); //=> '2004'
    349. 

  349.           *
    350. 

  350.           * //convert times
    351. 

  351.           * patio.dateToString(time); //=> '12:12:12'
    352. 

  352.           *
    353. 

  353.           * //convert dates
    354. 

  354.           * patio.dateToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01'
    355. 

  355.           * patio.dateFormat = patio.TWO_YEAR_DATE_FORMAT;
    356. 

  356.           * patio.dateToString(date); //=> '04-02-01'
    357. 

  357.           * patio.dateFormat = patio.DEFAULT_DATE_FORMAT;
    358. 

  358.           * patio.dateToString(date); //=> '2004-02-01'
    359. 

  359.  
    360. 

  360.           * //convert dateTime
    361. 

  361.           * patio.dateToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    362. 

  362.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DATETIME_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    363. 

  363.           * patio.dateToString(dateTime); //=> '04-02-01 12:12:12'
    364. 

  364.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DATETIME_FORMAT_TZ;
    365. 

  365.           * patio.dateToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'
    366. 

  366.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.ISO_8601;
    367. 

  367.           * patio.dateToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    368. 

  368.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR;
    369. 

  369.           * patio.dateToString(dateTime); //=> '04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    370. 

  370.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DEFAULT_DATETIME_FORMAT;
    371. 

  371.           * patio.dateToString(dateTime); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    372. 

  372.  
    373. 

  373.           * //convert timestamps
    374. 

  374.           * patio.dateToString(timeStamp); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    375. 

  375.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.TIMESTAMP_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    376. 

  376.           * patio.dateToString(timeStamp); //=> '04-02-01 12:12:12'
    377. 

  377.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.TIMESTAMP_FORMAT_TZ;
    378. 

  378.           * patio.dateToString(timeStamp); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'
    379. 

  379.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.ISO_8601;
    380. 

  380.           * patio.dateToString(timeStamp); //=> '2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    381. 

  381.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR;
    382. 

  382.           * patio.dateToString(timeStamp); //=> '04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'
    383. 

  383.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT;
    384. 

  384.           * patio.dateToString(timeStamp); //=> '2004-02-01 12:12:12'
    385. 

  385.           *
    386. 

  386.           * @param {Date\patio.sql.Time|patio.sql.Year|patio.sql.DateTime|patio.sql.TimeStamp} dt the date to covert to to a string.
    387. 

  387.           *
    388. 

  388.           * @returns {String} the date string.
    389. 

  389.           */
    390. 

  390.          dateToString:function (dt, format) {
    391. 

  391. 61            var ret = "";
    392. 

  392. 61            if (isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.Time)) {
    393. 

  393. 2                ret = this.timeToString(dt, format);
    394. 

  394. 59            } else if (isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.Year)) {
    395. 

  395. 4                ret = this.yearToString(dt, format);
    396. 

  396. 55            } else if (isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.DateTime)) {
    397. 

  397. 34                ret = this.dateTimeToString(dt, format);
    398. 

  398. 21            } else if (isInstanceOf(dt, SQL.TimeStamp)) {
    399. 

  399. 9                ret = this.timeStampToString(dt, format);
    400. 

  400. 12            } else if (isDate(dt)) {
    401. 

  401. 12                ret = dateFormat(dt, format || this.dateFormat);
    402. 

  402.              }
    403. 

  403. 61            return ret;
    404. 

  404.          },
    405. 

  405.  
    406. 

  406.          /**
    407. 

  407.           * Converts a year date string to a {@link patio.sql.Year}
    408. 

  408.           *
    409. 

  409.           * @example
    410. 

  410.           *
    411. 

  411.           * var year = new sql.Year(2004);
    412. 

  412.           * patio.stringToYear("2004"); //=> year
    413. 

  413.           * patio.yearFormat = "yy";
    414. 

  414.           * patio.stringToYear("04"); //=> year
    415. 

  415.           *
    416. 

  416.           * @param {String} dt the string to covert to a {@link patio.sql.Year}
    417. 

  417.           * @param {String} [format=patio.Time#yearFormat] the format to use when converting the date.
    418. 

  418.           *
    419. 

  419.           * @throws {PatioError} thrown if the conversion fails.
    420. 

  420.           * @return {patio.sql.Year} the {@link patio.sql.Year}
    421. 

  421.           */
    422. 

  422.          stringToYear:function (dt, format) {
    423. 

  423. 5            var ret = date.parse(dt, format || this.yearFormat);
    424. 

  424. 5            if (!ret) {
    425. 

  425. 1                throw new PatioError("Unable to convert year: " + dt);
    426. 

  426.              }
    427. 

  427. 4            return new SQL.Year(ret);
    428. 

  428.          },
    429. 

  429.  
    430. 

  430.          /**
    431. 

  431.           * Converts a time date string to a {@link patio.sql.Time}
    432. 

  432.           *
    433. 

  433.           * @example
    434. 

  434.           *
    435. 

  435.           * var time = new sql.Time(12,12,12);
    436. 

  436.           * patio.stringToTime("12:12:12"); //=> time
    437. 

  437.           *
    438. 

  438.           * @param {String} dt the string to convert to a {@link patio.sql.Time}
    439. 

  439.           * @param {String} [format=patio.Time#timeFormat] the format to use when converting the date.
    440. 

  440.           *
    441. 

  441.           * @throws {PatioError} thrown if the conversion fails.
    442. 

  442.           * @return {patio.sql.Time} the {@link patio.sql.Time}
    443. 

  443.           */
    444. 

  444.          stringToTime:function (dt, format) {
    445. 

  445. 12            var ret = date.parse(dt, format || this.timeFormat);
    446. 

  446. 12            if (!ret) {
    447. 

  447. 7                throw new PatioError("Unable to convert time: " + dt);
    448. 

  448.              }
    449. 

  449. 5            return new SQL.Time(ret);
    450. 

  450.          },
    451. 

  451.  
    452. 

  452.          /**
    453. 

  453.           * Converts a date string to a Date
    454. 

  454.           *
    455. 

  455.           * @example
    456. 

  456.           *
    457. 

  457.           * var date = new Date(2004, 1,1,0,0,0);
    458. 

  458.           * patio.stringToDate('2004-02-01'); //=> date
    459. 

  459.           *
    460. 

  460.           * patio.dateFormat = patio.TWO_YEAR_DATE_FORMAT;
    461. 

  461.           * patio.stringToDate('04-02-01'); //=> date
    462. 

  462.           *
    463. 

  463.           * @param {String} dt the string to convert to a Date
    464. 

  464.           * @param {String} [format=patio.Time#dateFormat] the format to use when converting the date.
    465. 

  465.           *
    466. 

  466.           * @throws {PatioError} thrown if the conversion fails.
    467. 

  467.           * @return {Date} the {@link Date}
    468. 

  468.           */
    469. 

  469.          stringToDate:function (dt, format) {
    470. 

  470. 19            var ret;
    471. 

  471. 19            if (this.convertTwoDigitYears) {
    472. 

  472. 19                ret = date.parse(dt, this.TWO_YEAR_DATE_FORMAT);
    473. 

  473.              }
    474. 

  474. 19            if (!ret) {
    475. 

  475. 9                ret = date.parse(dt, format || this.dateFormat);
    476. 

  476.              }
    477. 

  477. 19            if (!ret) {
    478. 

  478. 9                throw new PatioError("Unable to convert date: " + dt);
    479. 

  479.              }
    480. 

  480. 10            return ret;
    481. 

  481.          },
    482. 

  482.  
    483. 

  483.          /**
    484. 

  484.           * Converts a datetime date string to a {@link patio.sql.DateTime}
    485. 

  485.           *
    486. 

  486.           * @example
    487. 

  487.           *
    488. 

  488.           *  var dateTime = new sql.DateTime(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12),
    489. 

  489.           * offset = getTimeZoneOffset();
    490. 

  490.           * patio.stringToDateTime('2004-02-01 12:12:12'); //=> dateTime
    491. 

  491.           *
    492. 

  492.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DATETIME_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    493. 

  493.           * patio.stringToDateTime('04-02-01 12:12:12-0600'); //=> dateTime
    494. 

  494.           *
    495. 

  495.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.DATETIME_FORMAT_TZ;
    496. 

  496.           * patio.stringToDateTime('2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'); //=> dateTime
    497. 

  497.           *
    498. 

  498.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.ISO_8601;
    499. 

  499.           * patio.stringToDateTime('2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'); //=> dateTime
    500. 

  500.           *
    501. 

  501.           * patio.dateTimeFormat = patio.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR;
    502. 

  502.           * patio.stringToDateTime('04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'); //=> dateTime
    503. 

  503.           *
    504. 

  504.           * @param {String} dt the string to convert to a {@link patio.sql.DateTime}
    505. 

  505.           * @param {String} [format=patio.Time#dateTimeFormat] the format to use when converting the date.
    506. 

  506.           *
    507. 

  507.           * @throws {PatioError} thrown if the conversion fails.
    508. 

  508.           * @return {patio.sql.DateTime} the {@linkpatio.sql.DateTime}
    509. 

  509.           */
    510. 

  510.          stringToDateTime:function (dt, fmt) {
    511. 

  511. 21            var useT = dt.indexOf("T") != -1;
    512. 

  512.              //test if there is a T in the string so we can try to properly convert it
    513. 

  513. 21            var format = fmt ? fmt : useT ? this.ISO_8601 : this.DEFAULT_DATETIME_FORMAT;
    514. 

  514. 21            var ret = date.parse(dt, format);
    515. 

  515.              //if the coversion failed try it with a time zone
    516. 

  516. 21            !ret && (ret = date.parse(dt, this.DATETIME_FORMAT_TZ));
    517. 

  517. 21            if (!ret && this.convertTwoDigitYears) {
    518. 

  518.                  //if we still fail and we need to convert two digit years try the twoYearFormat
    519. 

  519. 10                var twoYearFormat = fmt ? fmt : useT ? this.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR : this.DATETIME_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    520. 

  520. 10                ret = date.parse(dt, twoYearFormat);
    521. 

  521.                  //try with time zone
    522. 

  522. 10                !ret && (ret = date.parse(dt, twoYearFormat + "Z"));
    523. 

  523.              }
    524. 

  524. 21            if (!ret) {
    525. 

  525. 10                throw new PatioError("Unable to convert datetime: " + dt);
    526. 

  526.              }
    527. 

  527. 11            return new SQL.DateTime(ret);
    528. 

  528.          },
    529. 

  529.  
    530. 

  530.          /**
    531. 

  531.           * Converts a timestamp date string to a {@link patio.sql.TimeStamp}
    532. 

  532.           *
    533. 

  533.           * @example
    534. 

  534.           *
    535. 

  535.           *  var timeStamp = new sql.TimeStamp(2004, 1, 1, 12, 12, 12);
    536. 

  536.           * patio.stringToTimeStamp('2004-02-01 12:12:12'); //=> timeStamp
    537. 

  537.           *
    538. 

  538.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.TIMESTAMP_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    539. 

  539.           * patio.stringToTimeStamp('04-02-01 12:12:12-0600'); //=> timeStamp
    540. 

  540.           *
    541. 

  541.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.TIMESTAMP_FORMAT_TZ;
    542. 

  542.           * patio.stringToTimeStamp('2004-02-01 12:12:12-0600'); //=> timeStamp
    543. 

  543.           *
    544. 

  544.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.ISO_8601;
    545. 

  545.           * patio.stringToTimeStamp('2004-02-01T12:12:12-0600'); //=> timeStamp
    546. 

  546.           *
    547. 

  547.           * patio.timeStampFormat = patio.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR;
    548. 

  548.           * patio.stringToTimeStamp('04-02-01T12:12:12-0600'); //=> timeStamp
    549. 

  549.           *
    550. 

  550.           * @param {String} dt the string to convert to a {@link patio.sql.TimeStamp}
    551. 

  551.           * @param {String} [format=patio.Time#timeStampFormat] the format to use when converting the date.
    552. 

  552.           *
    553. 

  553.           * @throws {PatioError} thrown if the conversion fails.
    554. 

  554.           * @return {patio.sql.TimeStamp} the {@link patio.sql.TimeStamp}
    555. 

  555.           */
    556. 

  556.          stringToTimeStamp:function (dt, fmt) {
    557. 

  557. 50            var useT = dt.indexOf("T") != -1;
    558. 

  558.              //test if there is a T in the string so we can try to properly convert it
    559. 

  559. 50            var format = fmt ? fmt : useT ? this.ISO_8601 : this.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT;
    560. 

  560. 50            var ret = date.parse(dt, format);
    561. 

  561.              //if the coversion failed try it with a time zone
    562. 

  562. 50            !ret && (ret = date.parse(dt, this.TIMESTAMP_FORMAT_TZ));
    563. 

  563. 50            if (!ret && this.convertTwoDigitYears) {
    564. 

  564.                  //if we still fail and we need to convert two digit years try the twoYearFormat
    565. 

  565. 4                var twoYearFormat = fmt ? fmt : useT ? this.ISO_8601_TWO_YEAR : this.TIMESTAMP_TWO_YEAR_FORMAT;
    566. 

  566. 4                ret = date.parse(dt, twoYearFormat);
    567. 

  567.                  //try with time zone
    568. 

  568. 4                !ret && (ret = date.parse(dt, twoYearFormat + "Z"));
    569. 

  569.              }
    570. 

  570. 50            if (!ret) {
    571. 

  571. 4                throw new PatioError("Unable to convert timestamp: " + dt);
    572. 

  572.              }
    573. 

  573. 46            return new SQL.TimeStamp(ret);
    574. 

  574.          },
    575. 

  575.  
    576. 

  576.  
    577. 

  577.          /**@ignore*/
    578. 

  578.          getters:{
    579. 

  579.              /**@ignore*/
    580. 

  580.  
    581. 

  581.              /**@ignore*/
    582. 

  582.              dateFormat:function (format) {
    583. 

  583. 21                return isUndefined(this.__dateFormat) ? this.DEFAULT_DATE_FORMAT : this.__dateFormat;
    584. 

  584.              },
    585. 

  585.              /**@ignore*/
    586. 

  586.              yearFormat:function (format) {
    587. 

  587. 13                return isUndefined(this.__yearFormat) ? this.DEFAULT_YEAR_FORMAT : this.__yearFormat;
    588. 

  588.              },
    589. 

  589.              /**@ignore*/
    590. 

  590.              timeFormat:function (format) {
    591. 

  591. 17                return isUndefined(this.__timeFormat) ? this.DEFAULT_TIME_FORMAT : this.__timeFormat;
    592. 

  592.              },
    593. 

  593.              /**@ignore*/
    594. 

  594.              timeStampFormat:function (format) {
    595. 

  595. 20                return isUndefined(this.__timeStampFormat) ? this.DEFAULT_TIMESTAMP_FORMAT : this.__timeStampFormat;
    596. 

  596.              },
    597. 

  597.              /**@ignore*/
    598. 

  598.              dateTimeFormat:function (format) {
    599. 

  599. 19                return isUndefined(this.__dateTimeFormat) ? this.DEFAULT_DATETIME_FORMAT : this.__dateTimeFormat;
    600. 

  600.              }
    601. 

  601.          },
    602. 

  602.  
    603. 

  603.  
    604. 

  604.          /**@ignore*/
    605. 

  605.          setters:{
    606. 

  606.              /**@ignore*/
    607. 

  607.  
    608. 

  608.              /**@ignore*/
    609. 

  609.              dateFormat:function (format) {
    610. 

  610. 6                this.__dateFormat = format;
    611. 

  611.              },
    612. 

  612.              /**@ignore*/
    613. 

  613.              yearFormat:function (format) {
    614. 

  614. 6                this.__yearFormat = format;
    615. 

  615.              },
    616. 

  616.              /**@ignore*/
    617. 

  617.              timeFormat:function (format) {
    618. 

  618. 2                this.__timeFormat = format;
    619. 

  619.              },
    620. 

  620.              /**@ignore*/
    621. 

  621.              timeStampFormat:function (format) {
    622. 

  622. 15                this.__timeStampFormat = format;
    623. 

  623.              },
    624. 

  624.              /**@ignore*/
    625. 

  625.              dateTimeFormat:function (format) {
    626. 

  626. 15                this.__dateTimeFormat = format;
    627. 

  627.              }
    628. 

  628.          }
    629. 

  629.      }
    630. 

  630.  }).as(module);
